pledged to fight a civil war against the whites. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_56"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_56"></span>**<sup>56</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_56)They were, and are, dedicated workers who are prepared to lead campaigns initiated by the ANC to distribute leaflets, to organize strikes, or do whatever the particular campaign required. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_57"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_57"></span>**<sup>57</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_57)They are called volunteers because they volunteer to face the penalties of imprisonment and whipping which are now prescribed by the legislature for such acts.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_58"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_58"></span>**<sup>58</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_58)<span style="color:#FF6600">During the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Defiance</st1:city></st1:place> Campaign, the Public Safety Act and the Criminal Law Amendment Act were passed. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_59"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_59"></span>**<sup>59</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_59)These Statutes provided harsher penalties for offences committed by way of protests against laws. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_60"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_60"></span>**<sup>60</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_60)Despite this, the protests continued and the ANC adhered to its policy of non-violence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_61"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_61"></span>**<sup>61</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_61)In 1956, 156 leading members of the Congress Alliance, including myself, were arrested on a charge of high treason and charges under the Suppression of Communism Act.  
<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_62"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_62"></span>**<sup>62</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_62)The non-violent policy of the ANC was put in issue by the State, but when the Court gave judgement some five years later, it found that the ANC did not have a policy of violence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_63"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_63"></span>**<sup>63</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_63)We were acquitted on all counts, which included a count that the ANC sought to set up a communist state in place of the existing regime. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_64"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_64"></span>**<sup>64</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_64)The Government has always sought to label all its opponents as communists. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_65"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_65"></span>**<sup>65</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_65)This allegation has been repeated in the present case, but as I will show, the ANC is not, and never has been, a communist organization.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_66"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_66"></span>**<sup>66</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_66)<span style="color:#FF6600">In 1960 there was the shooting at Sharpeville, which resulted in the proclamation of a state of emergency and the declaration of the ANC as an unlawful organization. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_67"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_67"></span>**<sup>67</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_67)My colleagues and I, after careful consideration, decided that we would not obey this decree. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_68"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_68"></span>**<sup>68</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_68)The African people were not part of the Government and did not make the laws by which they were governed. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_69"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_69"></span>**<sup>69</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_69)We believed in the words of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, that ‘the will of the people shall be the basis of authority of the Government,’ and for us to accept the banning was equivalent to accepting the silencing of the Africans for all time. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_70"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_70"></span>**<sup>70</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_70)The ANC refused to dissolve, but instead went underground. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_71"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_71"></span>**<sup>71</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_71)We believed it was our duty to preserve this organization which had been built up with almost fifty years of unremitting toil. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_72"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_72"></span>**<sup>72</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_72)I have no doubt that no self-respecting White political organization would disband itself if declared illegal by a government in which it had no say.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_73"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_73"></span>**<sup>73</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_73)Năm 1960 Nhà Nước cầm quyền tổ chức một cuộc trưng cầu dân ý mà từ đó nhà nước Cộng Hòa được thành lập. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_74"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_74"></span>**<sup>74</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_74)Người Phi Châu, những người chiếm 70% dân số Nam Phi, không có quyền để bầu cử và họ thậm chí cũng không được tham khảo ý kiến về những kiến nghị thay đổi hiến pháp. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_75"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_75"></span>**<sup>75</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_75)Tất cả chúng tôi nhận thức rất rõ tương lai của mình bị đặt dưới Nhà Nước Cộng Hòa của Người Da Trắng được đề nghị, và do vậy đã có quyết định tổ chức một Hội Thảo Tất cả Những Người Phi Châu để kêu gọi một Cuộc triệu tập Quốc gia, và tổ chức hàng loạt các cuộc biểu tình biểu dương lực lượng. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_76"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_76"></span>**<sup>76</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_76)<span style="color:#FF6600">The conference was attended by Africans of various political persuasions. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_77"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_77"></span>**<sup>77</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_77)I was the Secretary of the conference and undertook to be responsible for organizing the national stay-at-home which was subsequently called to coincide with the declaration of the Republic.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_78"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_78"></span>**<sup>78</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_78)Vì tất cả những cuộc biểu tình do người Phi châu tổ chức là bất hợp pháp, người tổ chức những cuộc biểu tình này phải tránh bị bắt. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_79"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_79"></span>**<sup>79</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_79)Tôi đã được chọn làm người này, và hệ quả tất yếu là tôi phải rời bỏ nhà và gia đình tôi và công việc của mình và tìm cách trốn tránh để tránh bị bắt.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_80"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_80"></span>**<sup>80</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_80)<span style="color:#FF6600">The stay-at-home, in accordance with ANC policy, was to be a peaceful demonstration. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_81"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_81"></span>**<sup>81</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_81)Careful instructions were given to organizers and members to avoid any recourse to violence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_82"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_82"></span>**<sup>82</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_82)The Government’s answer was to introduce new and harsher laws, to mobilize its armed forces, and to send Saracens, armed vehicles, and soldiers into the townships in a massive show of force designed to intimidate the people. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_83"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_83"></span>**<sup>83</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_83)This was an indication that the Government had decided to rule by force alone, and this decision was a milestone on the road to Umkhonto.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_84"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_84"></span>**<sup>84</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_84)<span style="color:#FF6600">Some of this may appear irrelevant to this trial. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_85"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_85"></span>**<sup>85</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_85)In fact, I believe none of it is irrelevant because it will, I hope, enable the Court to appreciate the attitude eventually adopted by the various persons and bodies concerned in the National Liberation Movement. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_86"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_86"></span>**<sup>86</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_86)When I went to jail in 1962, the dominant idea was that loss of life should be avoided. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_87"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_87"></span>**<sup>87</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_87)I now know that this was still so in 1963.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_88"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_88"></span>**<sup>88</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_88)Tôi phải quay trở lại thời điểm tháng 6 năm 1961\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_89"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_89"></span>**<sup>89</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_89)Lúc đó chúng tôi, những người lãnh đạo đồng bào chúng tôi, phải làm gì? <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_90"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_90"></span>**<sup>90</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_90)Có phải chúng tôi phải đầu hàng trước sự biểu dương vũ lực và sự đe dọa ngầm đàn áp các hành động trong tương lai, hay là chúng tôi phải chiến đấu chống lại và, như vậy, bằng cách nào?

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_91"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_91"></span>**<sup>91</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_91)<span style="color:#FF6600">We had no doubt that we had to continue the fight. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_92"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_92"></span>**<sup>92</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_92)Anything else would have been abject surrender. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_93"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_93"></span>**<sup>93</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_93)Our problem was not whether to fight, but was how to continue the fight. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_94"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_94"></span>**<sup>94</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_94)We of the ANC had always stood for a non-racial democracy, and we shrank from any action which might drive the races further apart than they already were.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_95"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_95"></span>**<sup>95</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_95)<span style="color:#FF6600">But the hard facts were that fifty years of non-violence had brought the African people nothing but more and more repressive legislation, and fewer and fewer rights. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_96"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_96"></span>**<sup>96</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_96)It may not be easy for this Court to understand, but it is a fact that for a long time the people had been talking of violence – of the day when they would fight the White man and win back their country – and we, the leaders of the ANC, had nevertheless always prevailed upon them to avoid violence and to pursue peaceful methods. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_97"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_97"></span>**<sup>97</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_97)When some of us discussed this in May and June of 1961, it could not be denied that our policy to achieve a non-racial State by non-violence had achieved nothing, and that our followers were beginning to lose confidence in this policy and were developing disturbing ideas of terrorism.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_98"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_98"></span>**<sup>98</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_98)Chúng ta không được phép quên rằng đến giờ này bạo lực, trong thực tế, đã trở thành đặc điểm của chính trường Nam Phi. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_99"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_99"></span>**<sup>99</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_99)Bạo lực đã xảy ra vào năm 1957 khi những người phụ nữ Zeerust bị ra lệnh phải mang thẻ lưu hành; vào năm 1958 khi thi hành luật lựa chọn gia súc ở Skhukhuniland; vào năm 1959 khi người dân Cato Manor biểu tình chống lại những cuộc đột kích khám xét thẻ lưu hành; vào năm 1960 khi Nhà Nước cố gắng áp đặt đạo luật Bantu Authorities vào vùng Pondoland. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_100"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_100"></span>**<sup>100</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_100)39 người Phi Châu đã chết trong những rối loạn này. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_101"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_101"></span>**<sup>101</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_101)Năm 1961 đã có những cuộc bạo loạn ở Warmbaths, và vùng <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Transkei</st1:country-region></st1:place> đã luôn luôn là một khối bất ổn sôi sục. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_102"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_102"></span>**<sup>102</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_102)Mỗi cuộc bạo loạn đều chỉ ra một cách rõ ràng một niềm tin lớn dần hiển nhiên trong lòng người Phi Châu rằng bạo lực là cách duy nhất để giải quyết mọi thứ – nó cho thấy rằng Nhà Nước nào sử dụng vũ lực để duy trì thể chế của họ cũng dạy cho những người bị áp bức sử dụng vũ lực để chống lại Nhà nước.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_103"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_103"></span>**<sup>103</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_103)<span style="color:#FF6600">Already small groups had arisen in the urban areas and were spontaneously making plans for violent forms of political struggle. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_104"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_104"></span>**<sup>104</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_104)There now arose a danger that these groups would adopt terrorism against Africans, as well as Whites, if not properly directed. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_105"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_105"></span>**<sup>105</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_105)Particularly disturbing was the type of violence engendered in places such as Zeerust, Sekhukhuniland, and Pondoland amongst Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_106"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_106"></span>**<sup>106</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_106)It was increasingly taking the form, not of struggle against the Government – though this is what prompted it – but of civil strife amongst themselves, conducted in such a way that it could not hope to achieve anything other than a loss of life and bitterness.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_107"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_107"></span>**<sup>107</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_107)Đầu tháng 6/1961, sau một thời gian dài đánh giá tình hình Nam Phi nhiều lo âu, tôi, và một số đồng sự, đã đi đến kết luận rằng khi bạo lực ở đất nước này là không thể tránh khỏi, sẽ là thiếu thực tế và không đúng nếu những người lãnh đạo Phi Châu tiếp tục thuyết giảng về hòa bình và phi bạo lực vào thời điểm mà Nhà Nước đáp trả lại những yêu cầu hòa bình của chúng ta bằng vũ lực.  
<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_108"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_108"></span>**<sup>108</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_108)<span style="color:#FF6600">This conclusion was not easily arrived at. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_109"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_109"></span>**<sup>109</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_109)It was only when all else had failed, when all channels of peaceful protest had been barred to us, that the decision was made to embark on violent forms of political struggle, and to form Umkhonto we Sizwe. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_110"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_110"></span>**<sup>110</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_110)We did so not because we desired such a course, but solely because the Government had left us with no other choice. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_111"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_111"></span>**<sup>111</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_111)In the Manifesto of Umkhonto published on 16 December 1961, which is Exhibit AD, we said: “The time comes in the life of any nation when there remain only two choices – submit or fight. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_112"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_112"></span>**<sup>112</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_112)That time has now come to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_113"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_113"></span>**<sup>113</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_113)We shall not submit and we have no choice but to hit back by all means in our power in defence of our people, our future, and our freedom.”</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_114"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_114"></span>**<sup>114</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_114)<span style="color:#FF6600">This was our feeling in June of 1961 when we decided to press for a change in the policy of the National Liberation Movement. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_115"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_115"></span>**<sup>115</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_115)I can only say that I felt morally obliged to do what I did.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_116"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_116"></span>**<sup>116</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_116)<span style="color:#FF6600">We who had taken this decision started to consult leaders of various organizations, including the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_117"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_117"></span>**<sup>117</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_117)I will not say whom we spoke to, or what they said, but I wish to deal with the role of the African National Congress in this phase of the struggle, and with the policy and objectives of Umkhonto we Sizwe.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_118"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_118"></span>**<sup>118</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_118)<span style="color:#FF6600">As far as the ANC was concerned, it formed a clear view which can be summarized as follows:</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_119"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_119"></span>**<sup>119</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_119)<span style="color:#FF6600">• It was a mass political organization with a political function to fulfil. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_120"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_120"></span>**<sup>120</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_120)Its members had joined on the express policy of non-violence.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_121"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_121"></span>**<sup>121</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_121)<span style="color:#FF6600">• Because of all this, it could not and would not undertake violence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_122"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_122"></span>**<sup>122</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_122)This must be stressed. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_123"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_123"></span>**<sup>123</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_123)One cannot turn such a body into the small, closely knit organization required for sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_124"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_124"></span>**<sup>124</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_124)Nor would this be politically correct, because it would result in members ceasing to carry out this essential activity: political propaganda and organization. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_125"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_125"></span>**<sup>125</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_125)Nor was it permissible to change the whole nature of the organization.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_126"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_126"></span>**<sup>126</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_126)<span style="color:#FF6600">• On the other hand, in view of this situation I have described, the ANC was prepared to depart from its fifty-year-old policy of non-violence to this extent that it would no longer disapprove of properly controlled violence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_127"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_127"></span>**<sup>127</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_127)Hence members who undertook such activity would not be subject to disciplinary action by the ANC.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_128"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_128"></span>**<sup>128</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_128)<span style="color:#FF6600">I say ‘properly controlled violence’ because I made it clear that if I formed the organization I would at all times subject it to the political guidance of the ANC and would not undertake any different form of activity from that contemplated without the consent of the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_129"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_129"></span>**<sup>129</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_129)And I shall now tell the Court how that form of violence came to be determined.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_130"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_130"></span>**<sup>130</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_130)<span style="color:#FF6600">As a result of this decision, Umkhonto was formed in November 1961\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_131"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_131"></span>**<sup>131</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_131)When we took this decision, and subsequently formulated our plans, the ANC heritage of non-violence and racial harmony was very much with us. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_132"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_132"></span>**<sup>132</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_132)We felt that the country was drifting towards a civil war in which Blacks and Whites would fight each other. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_133"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_133"></span>**<sup>133</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_133)We viewed the situation with alarm. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_134"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_134"></span>**<sup>134</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_134)Civil war could mean the destruction of what the ANC stood for; with civil war, racial peace would be more difficult than ever to achieve. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_135"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_135"></span>**<sup>135</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_135)We already have examples in South African history of the results of war. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_136"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_136"></span>**<sup>136</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_136)It has taken more than fifty years for the scars of the South African War to disappear. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_137"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_137"></span>**<sup>137</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_137)How much longer would it take to eradicate the scars of inter-racial civil war, which could not be fought without a great loss of life on both sides?</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_138"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_138"></span>**<sup>138</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_138)<span style="color:#FF6600">The avoidance of civil war had dominated our thinking for many years, but when we decided to adopt violence as part of our policy, we realized that we might one day have to face the prospect of such a war. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_139"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_139"></span>**<sup>139</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_139)This had to be taken into account in formulating our plans. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_140"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_140"></span>**<sup>140</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_140)We required a plan which was flexible and which permitted us to act in accordance with the needs of the times; above all, the plan had to be one which recognized civil war as the last resort, and left the decision on this question to the future. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_141"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_141"></span>**<sup>141</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_141)We did not want to be committed to civil war, but we wanted to be ready if it became inevitable.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_142"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_142"></span>**<sup>142</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_142)<span style="color:#FF6600">Four forms of violence were possible. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_143"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_143"></span>**<sup>143</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_143)There is sabotage, there is guerrilla warfare, there is terrorism, and there is open revolution. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_144"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_144"></span>**<sup>144</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_144)We chose to adopt the first method and to exhaust it before taking any other decision.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_145"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_145"></span>**<sup>145</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_145)<span style="color:#FF6600">In the light of our political background the choice was a logical one. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_146"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_146"></span>**<sup>146</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_146)Sabotage did not involve loss of life, and it offered the best hope for future race relations. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_147"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_147"></span>**<sup>147</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_147)Bitterness would be kept to a minimum and, if the policy bore fruit, democratic government could become a reality. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_148"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_148"></span>**<sup>148</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_148)This is what we felt at the time, and this is what we said in our Manifesto (Exhibit AD):</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_149"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_149"></span>**<sup>149</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_149)<span style="color:#FF6600">“We of Umkhonto we Sizwe have always sought to achieve liberation without bloodshed and civil clash. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_150"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_150"></span>**<sup>150</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_150)We hope, even at this late hour, that our first actions will awaken everyone to a realization of the disastrous situation to which the Nationalist policy is leading. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_151"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_151"></span>**<sup>151</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_151)We hope that we will bring the Government and its supporters to their senses before it is too late, so that both the Government and its policies can be changed before matters reach the desperate state of civil war.”</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_152"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_152"></span>**<sup>152</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_152)<span style="color:#FF6600">The initial plan was based on a careful analysis of the political and economic situation of our country. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_153"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_153"></span>**<sup>153</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_153)We believed that <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> depended to a large extent on foreign capital and foreign trade. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_154"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_154"></span>**<sup>154</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_154)We felt that planned destruction of power plants, and interference with rail and telephone communications, would tend to scare away capital from the country, make it more difficult for goods from the industrial areas to reach the seaports on schedule, and would in the long run be a heavy drain on the economic life of the country, thus compelling the voters of the country to reconsider their position.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_155"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_155"></span>**<sup>155</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_155)<span style="color:#FF6600">Attacks on the economic life-lines of the country were to be linked with sabotage on Government buildings and other symbols of apartheid. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_156"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_156"></span>**<sup>156</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_156)These attacks would serve as a source of inspiration to our people. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_157"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_157"></span>**<sup>157</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_157)In addition, they would provide an outlet for those people who were urging the adoption of violent methods and would enable us to give concrete proof to our followers that we had adopted a stronger line and were fighting back against Government violence.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_158"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_158"></span>**<sup>158</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_158)<span style="color:#FF6600">In addition, if mass action were successfully organized, and mass reprisals taken, we felt that sympathy for our cause would be roused in other countries, and that greater pressure would be brought to bear on the South African Government.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_159"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_159"></span>**<sup>159</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_159)<span style="color:#FF6600">This then was the plan. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_160"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_160"></span>**<sup>160</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_160)Umkhonto was to perform sabotage, and strict instructions were given to its members right from the start, that on no account were they to injure or kill people in planning or carrying out operations. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_161"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_161"></span>**<sup>161</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_161)These instructions have been referred to in the evidence of ‘Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_162"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_162"></span>**<sup>162</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_162)X’ and ‘Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_163"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_163"></span>**<sup>163</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_163)Z.’</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_164"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_164"></span>**<sup>164</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_164)<span style="color:#FF6600">The affairs of the Umkhonto were controlled and directed by a National High Command, which had powers of co-option and which could, and did, appoint Regional Commands. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_165"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_165"></span>**<sup>165</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_165)The High Command was the body which determined tactics and targets and was in charge of training and finance. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_166"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_166"></span>**<sup>166</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_166)Under the High Command there were Regional Commands which were responsible for the direction of the local sabotage groups. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_167"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_167"></span>**<sup>167</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_167)Within the framework of the policy laid down by the National High Command, the Regional Commands had authority to select the targets to be attacked. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_168"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_168"></span>**<sup>168</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_168)They had no authority to go beyond the prescribed framework and thus had no authority to embark upon acts which endangered life, or which did not fit into the overall plan of sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_169"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_169"></span>**<sup>169</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_169)For instance, Umkhonto members were forbidden ever to go armed into operation. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_170"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_170"></span>**<sup>170</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_170)Incidentally, the terms High Command and Regional Command were an importation from the Jewish national underground organization Irgun Zvai Leumi, which operated in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Israel</st1:country-region></st1:place> between 1944 and 1948.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_171"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_171"></span>**<sup>171</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_171)<span style="color:#FF6600">Umkhonto had its first operation on 16 December 1961, when Government buildings in <st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">Port Elizabeth</st1:city> and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Durban</st1:city></st1:place> were attacked. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_172"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_172"></span>**<sup>172</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_172)The selection of targets is proof of the policy to which I have referred. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_173"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_173"></span>**<sup>173</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_173)Had we intended to attack life we would have selected targets where people congregated and not empty buildings and power stations. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_174"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_174"></span>**<sup>174</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_174)The sabotage which was committed before 16 December 1961 was the work of isolated groups and had no connection whatever with Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_175"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_175"></span>**<sup>175</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_175)In fact, some of these and a number of later acts were claimed by other organizations.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_176"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_176"></span>**<sup>176</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_176)<span style="color:#FF6600">The Manifesto of Umkhonto was issued on the day that operations commenced. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_177"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_177"></span>**<sup>177</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_177)The response to our actions and Manifesto among the white population was characteristically violent. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_178"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_178"></span>**<sup>178</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_178)The Government threatened to take strong action, and called upon its supporters to stand firm and to ignore the demands of the Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_179"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_179"></span>**<sup>179</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_179)The Whites failed to respond by suggesting change; they responded to our call by suggesting the laager.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_180"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_180"></span>**<sup>180</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_180)<span style="color:#FF6600">In contrast, the response of the Africans was one of encouragement. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_181"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_181"></span>**<sup>181</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_181)Suddenly there was hope again. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_182"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_182"></span>**<sup>182</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_182)Things were happening. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_183"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_183"></span>**<sup>183</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_183)People in the townships became eager for political news. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_184"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_184"></span>**<sup>184</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_184)A great deal of enthusiasm was generated by the initial successes, and people began to speculate on how soon freedom would be obtained.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_185"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_185"></span>**<sup>185</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_185)<span style="color:#FF6600">But we in Umkhonto weighed up the white response with anxiety. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_186"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_186"></span>**<sup>186</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_186)The lines were being drawn. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_187"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_187"></span>**<sup>187</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_187)The whites and blacks were moving into separate camps, and the prospects of avoiding a civil war were made less. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_188"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_188"></span>**<sup>188</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_188)The white newspapers carried reports that sabotage would be punished by death. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_189"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_189"></span>**<sup>189</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_189)If this was so, how could we continue to keep Africans away from terrorism?</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_190"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_190"></span>**<sup>190</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_190)Đã rất nhiều người Phi Châu đã chết như là hệ quả của những va chạm về màu da. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_191"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_191"></span>**<sup>191</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_191)Năm 1920 khi nhà lãnh đạo nổi tiếng Masabala bị bắt giữ trong nhà giam Cảng Elizabeth, 24 người trong một nhóm người Phi Châu tập họp lại để yêu cầu thả ông đã bị cảnh sát và thường dân da trắng giết hại. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_192"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_192"></span>**<sup>192</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_192)Năm 1921, hơn 100 người Phi Châu đã chết trong vụ Bulhoek. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_193"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_193"></span>**<sup>193</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_193)Năm 1924, hơn 200 người Phi Châu bị giết khi Tổng đốc Tây Nam Phi dẫn đầu lực lượng đàn áp một nhóm nổi loạn chống lại thuế về chó. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_194"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_194"></span>**<sup>194</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_194)Ngày 1/5/1950, 18 người Phi Châu đã chết vì bị cảnh sát nã súng vào trong khi biểu tình. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_195"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_195"></span>**<sup>195</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_195)Ngày 21/3/1960, 69 người Phi Châu không có vũ khí đã chết tại Sharpeville.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_196"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_196"></span>**<sup>196</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_196)Còn bao nhiêu Sharperville nữa sẽ xảy ra trong lịch sử của đất nước chúng ta? <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_197"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_197"></span>**<sup>197</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_197)Và còn bao nhiêu Sharperville nữa mà đất nước chúng ta có thể chịu đựng mà bạo lực và khủng bố không trở thành chuyện hàng ngày? <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_198"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_198"></span>**<sup>198</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_198)Và điều gì sẽ xảy ra cho đồng bào chúng ta khi tiến đến giai đoạn đó? <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_199"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_199"></span>**<sup>199</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_199)Trong tầm nhìn dài hạn, chúng tôi cảm giác rằng chúng tôi chắc chắn phải thành công, nhưng chúng tôi và cả nước còn lại phải trả bằng cái giá nào? <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_200"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_200"></span>**<sup>200</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_200)Và nếu điều này xảy ra, làm sao người da đen và người da trắng còn có thể sống chung với nhau trong hòa bình và hòa thuận? <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_201"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_201"></span>**<sup>201</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_201)Đây là những vấn đề đặt ra cho chúng ta, và đây là những quyết định của chúng tôi.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_202"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_202"></span>**<sup>202</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_202)<span style="color:#FF6600">Experience convinced us that rebellion would offer the Government limitless opportunities for the indiscriminate slaughter of our people. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_203"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_203"></span>**<sup>203</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_203)But it was precisely because the soil of <st1:country-region w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">South Africa</st1:place></st1:country-region> is already drenched with the blood of innocent Africans that we felt it our duty to make preparations as a long-term undertaking to use force in order to defend ourselves against force. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_204"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_204"></span>**<sup>204</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_204)If war were inevitable, we wanted the fight to be conducted on terms most favorable to our people. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_205"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_205"></span>**<sup>205</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_205)The fight which held out prospects best for us and the least risk of life to both sides was guerrilla warfare. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_206"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_206"></span>**<sup>206</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_206)We decided, therefore, in our preparations for the future, to make provision for the possibility of guerrilla warfare.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_207"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_207"></span>**<sup>207</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_207)<span style="color:#FF6600">All whites undergo compulsory military training, but no such training was given to Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_208"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_208"></span>**<sup>208</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_208)It was in our view essential to build up a nucleus of trained men who would be able to provide the leadership which would be required if guerrilla warfare started. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_209"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_209"></span>**<sup>209</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_209)We had to prepare for such a situation before it became too late to make proper preparations. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_210"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_210"></span>**<sup>210</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_210)It was also necessary to build up a nucleus of men trained in civil administration and other professions, so that Africans would be equipped to participate in the government of this country as soon as they were allowed to do so.</span>

**<sup><span style="color:#FF6600">[211](#E_dienvan_e_22_211)</span></sup>**<span style="color:#FF6600">At this stage it was decided that I should attend the Conference of the Pan-African Freedom Movement for Central, East, and Southern Africa, which was to be held early in 1962 in Addis Ababa, and, because of our need for preparation, it was also decided that, after the conference, I would undertake a tour of the African States with a view to obtaining facilities for the training of soldiers, and that I would also solicit scholarships for the higher education of matriculated Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_212"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_212"></span>**<sup>212</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_212)Training in both fields would be necessary, even if changes came about by peaceful means.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_213"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_213"></span>**<sup>213</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_213)<span style="color:#FF6600">Administrators would be necessary who would be willing and able to administer a non-racial State and so would men be necessary to control the army and police force of such a State.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_214"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_214"></span>**<sup>214</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_214)<span style="color:#FF6600">It was on this note that I left <st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region> to proceed to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Addis Ababa</st1:city></st1:place> as a delegate of the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_215"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_215"></span>**<sup>215</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_215)My tour was a success. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_211"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_211"></span>**<sup>211</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_211)Wherever I went I met sympathy for our cause and promises of help. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_216"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_216"></span>**<sup>216</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_216)All Africa was united against the stand of White South Africa, and even in <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">London</st1:place></st1:city> I was received with great sympathy by political leaders, such as Mr. Gaitskell and Mr. Grimond. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_217"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_217"></span>**<sup>217</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_217)In Africa I was promised support by such men as Julius Nyerere, now President of Tanganyika; Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_218"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_218"></span>**<sup>218</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_218)Kawawa, then Prime Minister of Tanganyika; Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia; General Abboud, President of the Sudan; Habib Bourguiba, President of Tunisia; Ben Bella, now President of Algeria; Modibo Keita, President of Mali; Leopold Senghor, President of Senegal; Sekou Toure, President of Guinea; President Tubman of Liberia; and Milton Obote, Prime Minister of Uganda. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_219"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_219"></span>**<sup>219</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_219)It was Ben Bella who invited me to visit Oujda, the Headquarters of the Algerian Army of National Liberation, the visit which is described in my diary, one of the Exhibits.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_220"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_220"></span>**<sup>220</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_220)<span style="color:#FF6600">I started to make a study of the art of war and revolution and, whilst abroad, underwent a course in military training. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_221"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_221"></span>**<sup>221</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_221)If there was to be guerrilla warfare, I wanted to be able to stand and fight with my people and to share the hazards of war with them. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_222"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_222"></span>**<sup>222</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_222)Notes of lectures which I received in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Algeria</st1:country-region></st1:place> are contained in Exhibit 16, produced in evidence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_223"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_223"></span>**<sup>223</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_223)Summaries of books on guerrilla warfare and military strategy have also been produced. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_224"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_224"></span>**<sup>224</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_224)I have already admitted that these documents are in my writing, and I acknowledge that I made these studies to equip myself for the role which I might have to play if the struggle drifted into guerrilla warfare. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_225"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_225"></span>**<sup>225</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_225)I approached this question as every African Nationalist should do. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_226"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_226"></span>**<sup>226</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_226)I was completely objective. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_227"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_227"></span>**<sup>227</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_227)The Court will see that I attempted to examine all types of authority on the subject – from the East and from the West, going back to the classic work of Clausewitz, and covering such a variety as Mao Tse Tung and Che Guevara on the one hand, and the writings on the Anglo-Boer War on the other. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_228"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_228"></span>**<sup>228</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_228)Of course, these notes are merely summaries of the books I read and do not contain my personal views.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_229"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_229"></span>**<sup>229</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_229)<span style="color:#FF6600">I also made arrangements for our recruits to undergo military training. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_230"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_230"></span>**<sup>230</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_230)But here it was impossible to organize any scheme without the co-operation of the ANC offices in <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_231"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_231"></span>**<sup>231</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_231)I consequently obtained the permission of the ANC in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> to do this. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_232"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_232"></span>**<sup>232</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_232)To this extent then there was a departure from the original decision of the ANC, but it applied outside <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> only. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_233"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_233"></span>**<sup>233</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_233)The first batch of recruits actually arrived in <st1:country-region w:st="on">Tanganyika</st1:country-region> when I was passing through that country on my way back to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_234"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_234"></span>**<sup>234</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_234)<span style="color:#FF6600">I returned to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> and reported to my colleagues on the results of my trip. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_235"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_235"></span>**<sup>235</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_235)On my return I found that there had been little alteration in the political scene save that the threat of a death penalty for sabotage had now become a fact. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_236"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_236"></span>**<sup>236</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_236)The attitude of my colleagues in Umkhonto was much the same as it had been before I left. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_237"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_237"></span>**<sup>237</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_237)They were feeling their way cautiously and felt that it would be a long time before the possibilities of sabotage were exhausted. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_238"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_238"></span>**<sup>238</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_238)In fact, the view was expressed by some that the training of recruits was premature. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_239"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_239"></span>**<sup>239</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_239)This is recorded by me in the document which is Exhibit R.14\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_240"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_240"></span>**<sup>240</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_240)After a full discussion, however, it was decided to go ahead with the plans for military training because of the fact that it would take many years to build up a sufficient nucleus of trained soldiers to start a guerrilla campaign, and whatever happened, the training would be of value.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_241"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_241"></span>**<sup>241</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_241)<span style="color:#FF6600">I wish to turn now to certain general allegations made in this case by the State. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_242"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_242"></span>**<sup>242</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_242)But before doing so, I wish to revert to certain occurrences said by witnesses to have happened in <st1:city w:st="on">Port Elizabeth</st1:city> and <st1:place w:st="on">East London</st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_243"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_243"></span>**<sup>243</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_243)I am referring to the bombing of private houses of pro-Government persons during September, October and November 1962\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_244"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_244"></span>**<sup>244</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_244)I do not know what justification there was for these acts, nor what provocation had been given. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_245"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_245"></span>**<sup>245</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_245)But if what I have said already is accepted, then it is clear that these acts had nothing to do with the carrying out of the policy of Umkhonto.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_246"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_246"></span>**<sup>246</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_246)<span style="color:#FF6600">One of the chief allegations in the indictment is that the ANC was a party to a general conspiracy to commit sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_247"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_247"></span>**<sup>247</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_247)I have already explained why this is incorrect but how, externally, there was a departure from the original principle laid down by the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_248"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_248"></span>**<sup>248</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_248)There has, of course, been overlapping of functions internally as well, because there is a difference between a resolution adopted in the atmosphere of a committee room and the concrete difficulties that arise in the field of practical activity. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_249"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_249"></span>**<sup>249</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_249)At a later stage the position was further affected by bannings and house arrests, and by persons leaving the country to take up political work abroad. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_250"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_250"></span>**<sup>250</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_250)This led to individuals having to do work in different capacities. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_251"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_251"></span>**<sup>251</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_251)But though this may have blurred the distinction between Umkhonto and the ANC, it by no means abolished that distinction. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_252"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_252"></span>**<sup>252</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_252)Great care was taken to keep the activities of the two organizations in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> distinct. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_253"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_253"></span>**<sup>253</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_253)The ANC remained a mass political body of Africans only carrying on the type of political work they had conducted prior to 1961\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_254"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_254"></span>**<sup>254</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_254)Umkhonto remained a small organization recruiting its members from different races and organizations and trying to achieve its own particular object. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_255"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_255"></span>**<sup>255</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_255)The fact that members of Umkhonto were recruited from the ANC, and the fact that persons served both organizations, like Solomon Mbanjwa, did not, in our view, change the nature of the ANC or give it a policy of violence. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_256"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_256"></span>**<sup>256</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_256)This overlapping of officers, however, was more the exception than the rule. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_257"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_257"></span>**<sup>257</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_257)This is why persons such as ‘Mr. X’ and ‘Mr. Z,’ who were on the Regional Command of their respective areas, did not participate in any of the ANC committees or activities, and why people such as Mr. Bennett Mashiyana and Mr. Reginald Ndubi did not hear of sabotage at their ANC meetings.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_258"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_258"></span>**<sup>258</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_258)<span style="color:#FF6600">Another of the allegations in the indictment is that Rivonia was the headquarters of Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_259"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_259"></span>**<sup>259</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_259)This is not true of the time when I was there. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_260"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_260"></span>**<sup>260</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_260)I was told, of course, and knew that certain of the activities of the Communist Party were carried on there. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_261"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_261"></span>**<sup>261</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_261)But this is no reason (as I shall presently explain) why I should not use the place.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_262"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_262"></span>**<sup>262</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_262)<span style="color:#FF6600">I came there in the following manner:</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_263"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_263"></span>**<sup>263</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_263)As already indicated, early in April 1961 I went underground to organize the May general strike. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_264"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_264"></span>**<sup>264</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_264)My work entailed travelling throughout the country, living now in African townships, then in country villages and again in cities.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_265"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_265"></span>**<sup>265</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_265)During the second half of the year I started visiting the Parktown home of Arthur Goldreich, where I used to meet my family privately. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_266"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_266"></span>**<sup>266</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_266)Although I had no direct political association with him, I had known Arthur Goldreich socially since 1958.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_267"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_267"></span>**<sup>267</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_267)In October, Arthur Goldreich informed me that he was moving out of town and offered me a hiding place there. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_268"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_268"></span>**<sup>268</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_268)A few days thereafter, he arranged for Michael Harmel to take me to Rivonia. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_269"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_269"></span>**<sup>269</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_269)I naturally found Rivonia an ideal place for the man who lived the life of an outlaw. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_270"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_270"></span>**<sup>270</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_270)Up to that time I had been compelled to live indoors during the daytime and could only venture out under cover of darkness. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_271"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_271"></span>**<sup>271</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_271)But at Liliesleaf [farm, Rivonia,] I could live differently and work far more efficiently.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_272"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_272"></span>**<sup>272</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_272)For obvious reasons, I had to disguise myself and I assumed the fictitious name of David. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_273"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_273"></span>**<sup>273</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_273)In December, Arthur Goldreich and his family moved in. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_274"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_274"></span>**<sup>274</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_274)I stayed there until I went abroad on 11 January 1962\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_275"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_275"></span>**<sup>275</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_275)As already indicated, I returned in July 1962 and was arrested in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Natal</st1:city></st1:place> on 5 August.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_276"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_276"></span>**<sup>276</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_276)Up to the time of my arrest, Liliesleaf farm was the headquarters of neither the African National Congress nor Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_277"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_277"></span>**<sup>277</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_277)With the exception of myself, none of the officials or members of these bodies lived there, no meetings of the governing bodies were ever held there, and no activities connected with them were either organized or directed from there. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_278"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_278"></span>**<sup>278</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_278)On numerous occasions during my stay at Liliesleaf farm I met both the Executive Committee of the ANC, as well as the NHC, but such meetings were held elsewhere and not on the farm.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_279"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_279"></span>**<sup>279</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_279)Whilst staying at Liliesleaf farm, I frequently visited Arthur Goldreich in the main house and he also paid me visits in my room. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_280"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_280"></span>**<sup>280</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_280)We had numerous political discussions covering a variety of subjects. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_281"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_281"></span>**<sup>281</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_281)We discussed ideological and practical questions, the Congress Alliance, Umkhonto and its activities generally, and his experiences as a soldier in the Palmach, the military wing of the Haganah. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_282"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_282"></span>**<sup>282</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_282)Haganah was the political authority of the Jewish National Movement in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Palestine</st1:city></st1:place>.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_283"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_283"></span>**<sup>283</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_283)Because of what I had got to know of Goldreich, I recommended on my return to <st1:country-region w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">South Africa</st1:place></st1:country-region> that he should be recruited to Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_284"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_284"></span>**<sup>284</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_284)I do not know of my personal knowledge whether this was done.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_285"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_285"></span>**<sup>285</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_285)<span style="color:#FF6600">Another of the allegations made by the State is that the aims and objects of the ANC and the Communist Party are the same. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_286"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_286"></span>**<sup>286</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_286)I wish to deal with this and with my own political position, because I must assume that the State may try to argue from certain Exhibits that I tried to introduce Marxism into the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_287"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_287"></span>**<sup>287</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_287)The allegation as to the ANC is false. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_288"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_288"></span>**<sup>288</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_288)This is an old allegation which was disproved at the Treason Trial and which has again reared its head. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_289"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_289"></span>**<sup>289</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_289)But since the allegation has been made again, I shall deal with it as well as with the relationship between the ANC and the Communist Party and Umkhonto and that party.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_290"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_290"></span>**<sup>290</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_290)<span style="color:#FF6600">The ideological creed of the ANC is, and always has been, the creed of African Nationalism. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_291"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_291"></span>**<sup>291</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_291)It is not the concept of African Nationalism expressed in the cry, ‘Drive the White man into the sea.’ <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_292"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_292"></span>**<sup>292</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_292)The African Nationalism for which the ANC stands is the concept of freedom and fulfilment for the African people in their own land. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_293"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_293"></span>**<sup>293</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_293)The most important political document ever adopted by the ANC is the ‘Freedom Charter.’ <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_294"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_294"></span>**<sup>294</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_294)It is by no means a blueprint for a socialist state. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_295"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_295"></span>**<sup>295</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_295)It calls for redistribution, but not nationalization, of land; it provides for nationalization of mines, banks, and monopoly industry, because big monopolies are owned by one race only, and without such nationalization racial domination would be perpetuated despite the spread of political power. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_296"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_296"></span>**<sup>296</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_296)It would be a hollow gesture to repeal the Gold Law prohibitions against Africans when all gold mines are owned by European companies. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_297"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_297"></span>**<sup>297</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_297)In this respect the ANC’s policy corresponds with the old policy of the present Nationalist Party which, for many years, had as part of its programme the nationalization of the gold mines which, at that time, were controlled by foreign capital. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_298"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_298"></span>**<sup>298</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_298)Under the Freedom Charter, nationalization would take place in an economy based on private enterprise. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_299"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_299"></span>**<sup>299</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_299)The realization of the Freedom Charter would open up fresh fields for a prosperous African population of all classes, including the middle class. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_300"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_300"></span>**<sup>300</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_300)The ANC has never at any period of its history advocated a revolutionary change in the economic structure of the country, nor has it, to the best of my recollection, ever condemned capitalist society.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_301"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_301"></span>**<sup>301</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_301)<span style="color:#FF6600">As far as the Communist Party is concerned, and if I understand its policy correctly, it stands for the establishment of a State based on the principles of Marxism. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_302"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_302"></span>**<sup>302</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_302)Although it is prepared to work for the Freedom Charter, as a short term solution to the problems created by white supremacy, it regards the Freedom Charter as the beginning, and not the end, of its program.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_303"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_303"></span>**<sup>303</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_303)<span style="color:#FF6600">The ANC, unlike the Communist Party, admitted Africans only as members. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_304"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_304"></span>**<sup>304</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_304)Its chief goal was, and is, for the African people to win unity and full political rights. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_305"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_305"></span>**<sup>305</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_305)The Communist Party’s main aim, on the other hand, was to remove the capitalists and to replace them with a working-class government. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_306"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_306"></span>**<sup>306</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_306)The Communist Party sought to emphasize class distinctions whilst the ANC seeks to harmonize them. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_307"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_307"></span>**<sup>307</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_307)This is a vital distinction.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_308"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_308"></span>**<sup>308</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_308)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is true that there has often been close co-operation between the ANC and the Communist Party. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_309"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_309"></span>**<sup>309</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_309)But co-operation is merely proof of a common goal – in this case the removal of white supremacy – and is not proof of a complete community of interests.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_310"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_310"></span>**<sup>310</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_310)<span style="color:#FF6600">The history of the world is full of similar examples. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_311"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_311"></span>**<sup>311</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_311)Perhaps the most striking illustration is to be found in the co-operation between <st1:country-region w:st="on">Great Britain</st1:country-region>, the <st1:country-region w:st="on">United States of America</st1:country-region>, and the <st1:place w:st="on">Soviet Union</st1:place> in the fight against Hitler. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_312"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_312"></span>**<sup>312</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_312)Nobody but Hitler would have dared to suggest that such co-operation turned Churchill or Roosevelt into communists or communist tools, or that <st1:country-region w:st="on">Britain</st1:country-region> and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">America</st1:country-region></st1:place> were working to bring about a communist world.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_313"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_313"></span>**<sup>313</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_313)<span style="color:#FF6600">Another instance of such co-operation is to be found precisely in Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_314"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_314"></span>**<sup>314</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_314)Shortly after Umkhonto was constituted, I was informed by some of its members that the Communist Party would support Umkhonto, and this then occurred. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_315"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_315"></span>**<sup>315</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_315)At a later stage the support was made openly.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_316"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_316"></span>**<sup>316</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_316)<span style="color:#FF6600">I believe that communists have always played an active role in the fight by colonial countries for their freedom, because the short-term objects of communism would always correspond with the long-term objects of freedom movements. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_317"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_317"></span>**<sup>317</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_317)Thus communists have played an important role in the freedom struggles fought in countries such as <st1:city w:st="on">Malaya</st1:city>, <st1:country-region w:st="on">Algeria</st1:country-region>, and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Indonesia</st1:country-region></st1:place>, yet none of these States today are communist countries. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_318"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_318"></span>**<sup>318</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_318)Similarly in the underground resistance movements which sprung up in <st1:place w:st="on">Europe</st1:place> during the last World War, communists played an important role. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_319"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_319"></span>**<sup>319</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_319)Even General Chiang Kai-Shek, today one of the bitterest enemies of communism, fought together with the communists against the ruling class in the struggle which led to his assumption of power in China in the 1930s.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_320"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_320"></span>**<sup>320</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_320)<span style="color:#FF6600">This pattern of co-operation between communists and non-communists has been repeated in the National Liberation Movement of South Africa. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_321"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_321"></span>**<sup>321</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_321)Prior to the banning of the Communist Party, joint campaigns involving the Communist Party and the Congress movements were accepted practice. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_322"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_322"></span>**<sup>322</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_322)African communists could, and did, become members of the ANC, and some served on the National, Provincial, and local committees. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_323"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_323"></span>**<sup>323</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_323)Amongst those who served on the National Executive are Albert Nzula, a former Secretary of the Communist Party, Moses Kotane, another former Secretary, and J. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_324"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_324"></span>**<sup>324</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_324)B. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_325"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_325"></span>**<sup>325</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_325)Marks, a former member of the Central Committee.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_326"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_326"></span>**<sup>326</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_326)<span style="color:#FF6600">I joined the ANC in 1944, and in my younger days I held the view that the policy of admitting communists to the ANC, and the close co-operation which existed at times on specific issues between the ANC and the Communist Party, would lead to a watering down of the concept of African Nationalism. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_327"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_327"></span>**<sup>327</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_327)At that stage I was a member of the African National Congress Youth League, and was one of a group which moved for the expulsion of communists from the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_328"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_328"></span>**<sup>328</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_328)This proposal was heavily defeated. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_329"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_329"></span>**<sup>329</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_329)Amongst those who voted against the proposal were some of the most conservative sections of African political opinion. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_330"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_330"></span>**<sup>330</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_330)They defended the policy on the ground that from its inception the ANC was formed and built up, not as a political party with one school of political thought, but as a Parliament of the African people, accommodating people of various political convictions, all united by the common goal of national liberation. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_331"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_331"></span>**<sup>331</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_331)I was eventually won over to this point of view and I have upheld it ever since.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_332"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_332"></span>**<sup>332</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_332)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is perhaps difficult for white South Africans, with an ingrained prejudice against communism, to understand why experienced African politicians so readily accept communists as their friends. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_333"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_333"></span>**<sup>333</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_333)But to us the reason is obvious. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_334"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_334"></span>**<sup>334</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_334)Theoretical differences amongst those fighting against oppression is a luxury we cannot afford at this stage. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_335"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_335"></span>**<sup>335</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_335)What is more, for many decades communists were the only political group in South Africa who were prepared to treat Africans as human beings and their equals; who were prepared to eat with us; talk with us, live with us, and work with us. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_336"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_336"></span>**<sup>336</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_336)They were the only political group which was prepared to work with the Africans for the attainment of political rights and a stake in society. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_337"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_337"></span>**<sup>337</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_337)Because of this, there are many Africans who, today, tend to equate freedom with communism. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_338"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_338"></span>**<sup>338</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_338)They are supported in this belief by a legislature which brands all exponents of democratic government and African freedom as communists and bans many of them (who are not communists) under the Suppression of Communism Act. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_339"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_339"></span>**<sup>339</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_339)Although I have never been a member of the Communist Party, I myself have been named under that pernicious Act because of the role I played in the Defiance Campaign. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_340"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_340"></span>**<sup>340</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_340)I have also been banned and imprisoned under that Act.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_341"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_341"></span>**<sup>341</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_341)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is not only in internal politics that we count communists as amongst those who support our cause. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_342"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_342"></span>**<sup>342</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_342)In the international field, communist countries have always come to our aid. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_343"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_343"></span>**<sup>343</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_343)In the United Nations and other Councils of the world the communist bloc has supported the Afro-Asian struggle against colonialism and often seems to be more sympathetic to our plight than some of the Western powers. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_344"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_344"></span>**<sup>344</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_344)Although there is a universal condemnation of apartheid, the communist bloc speaks out against it with a louder voice than most of the white world. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_345"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_345"></span>**<sup>345</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_345)In these circumstances, it would take a brash young politician, such as I was in 1949, to proclaim that the Communists are our enemies.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_346"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_346"></span>**<sup>346</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_346)<span style="color:#FF6600">I turn now to my own position. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_347"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_347"></span>**<sup>347</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_347)I have denied that I am a communist, and I think that in the circumstances I am obliged to state exactly what my political beliefs are.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_348"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_348"></span>**<sup>348</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_348)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have always regarded myself, in the first place, as an African patriot. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_349"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_349"></span>**<sup>349</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_349)After all, I was born in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Umtata</st1:city></st1:place>, forty-six years ago. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_350"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_350"></span>**<sup>350</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_350)My guardian was my cousin, who was the acting paramount chief of Tembuland, and I am related both to the present paramount chief of Tembuland, Sabata Dalindyebo, and to Kaizer Matanzima, the Chief Minister of the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Transkei</st1:country-region></st1:place>.</span>
