<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_351"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_351"></span>**<sup>351</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_351)<span style="color:#FF6600">Today I am attracted by the idea of a classless society, an attraction which springs in part from Marxist reading and, in part, from my admiration of the structure and organization of early African societies in this country. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_352"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_352"></span>**<sup>352</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_352)The land, then the main means of production, belonged to the tribe. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_353"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_353"></span>**<sup>353</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_353)There were no rich or poor and there was no exploitation.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_354"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_354"></span>**<sup>354</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_354)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is true, as I have already stated, that I have been influenced by Marxist thought. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_355"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_355"></span>**<sup>355</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_355)But this is also true of many of the leaders of the new independent States. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_356"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_356"></span>**<sup>356</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_356)Such widely different persons as Gandhi, Nehru, Nkrumah, and Nasser all acknowledge this fact. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_357"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_357"></span>**<sup>357</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_357)We all accept the need for some form of socialism to enable our people to catch up with the advanced countries of this world and to overcome their legacy of extreme poverty. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_358"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_358"></span>**<sup>358</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_358)But this does not mean we are Marxists.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_359"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_359"></span>**<sup>359</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_359)<span style="color:#FF6600">Indeed, for my own part, I believe that it is open to debate whether the Communist Party has any specific role to play at this particular stage of our political struggle. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_360"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_360"></span>**<sup>360</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_360)The basic task at the present moment is the removal of race discrimination and the attainment of democratic rights on the basis of the Freedom Charter. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_361"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_361"></span>**<sup>361</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_361)In so far as that Party furthers this task, I welcome its assistance. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_362"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_362"></span>**<sup>362</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_362)I realize that it is one of the means by which people of all races can be drawn into our struggle.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_363"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_363"></span>**<sup>363</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_363)<span style="color:#FF6600">From my reading of Marxist literature and from conversations with Marxists, I have gained the impression that communists regard the parliamentary system of the West as undemocratic and reactionary. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_364"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_364"></span>**<sup>364</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_364)But, on the contrary, I am an admirer of such a system.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_365"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_365"></span>**<sup>365</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_365)<span style="color:#FF6600">The Magna Carta, the Petition of Rights, and the Bill of Rights are documents which are held in veneration by democrats throughout the world.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_366"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_366"></span>**<sup>366</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_366)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have great respect for British political institutions, and for the country’s system of justice. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_367"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_367"></span>**<sup>367</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_367)I regard the British Parliament as the most democratic institution in the world, and the independence and impartiality of its judiciary never fails to arouse my admiration.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_368"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_368"></span>**<sup>368</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_368)<span style="color:#FF6600">The American Congress, that country’s doctrine of separation of powers, as well as the independence of its judiciary, arouses in me similar sentiments.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_369"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_369"></span>**<sup>369</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_369)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have been influenced in my thinking by both West and East. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_370"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_370"></span>**<sup>370</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_370)All this has led me to feel that in my search for a political formula, I should be absolutely impartial and objective. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_371"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_371"></span>**<sup>371</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_371)I should tie myself to no particular system of society other than of socialism. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_372"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_372"></span>**<sup>372</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_372)I must leave myself free to borrow the best from the West and from the East...</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_373"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_373"></span>**<sup>373</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_373)<span style="color:#FF6600">There are certain Exhibits which suggest that we received financial support from abroad, and I wish to deal with this question.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_374"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_374"></span>**<sup>374</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_374)<span style="color:#FF6600">Our political struggle has always been financed from internal sources – from funds raised by our own people and by our own supporters. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_375"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_375"></span>**<sup>375</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_375)Whenever we had a special campaign or an important political case – for example, the Treason Trial – we received financial assistance from sympathetic individuals and organizations in the Western countries. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_376"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_376"></span>**<sup>376</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_376)We had never felt it necessary to go beyond these sources.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_377"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_377"></span>**<sup>377</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_377)<span style="color:#FF6600">But when in 1961 the Umkhonto was formed, and a new phase of struggle introduced, we realized that these events would make a heavy call on our slender resources, and that the scale of our activities would be hampered by the lack of funds. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_378"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_378"></span>**<sup>378</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_378)One of my instructions, as I went abroad in January 1962, was to raise funds from the African states.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_379"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_379"></span>**<sup>379</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_379)<span style="color:#FF6600">I must add that, whilst abroad, I had discussions with leaders of political movements in Africa and discovered that almost every single one of them, in areas which had still not attained independence, had received all forms of assistance from the socialist countries, as well as from the West, including that of financial support. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_380"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_380"></span>**<sup>380</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_380)I also discovered that some well-known African states, all of them non-communists, and even anti-communists, had received similar assistance.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_381"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_381"></span>**<sup>381</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_381)<span style="color:#FF6600">On my return to the Republic, I made a strong recommendation to the ANC that we should not confine ourselves to <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place> and the Western countries, but that we should also send a mission to the socialist countries to raise the funds which we so urgently needed.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_382"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_382"></span>**<sup>382</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_382)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have been told that after I was convicted such a mission was sent, but I am not prepared to name any countries to which it went, nor am I at liberty to disclose the names of the organizations and countries which gave us support or promised to do so.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_383"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_383"></span>**<sup>383</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_383)<span style="color:#FF6600">As I understand the State case, and in particular the evidence of ‘Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_384"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_384"></span>**<sup>384</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_384)X,’ the suggestion is that Umkhonto was the inspiration of the Communist Party which sought by playing upon imaginary grievances to enroll the African people into an army which ostensibly was to fight for African freedom, but in reality was fighting for a communist state. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_385"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_385"></span>**<sup>385</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_385)Nothing could be further from the truth. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_386"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_386"></span>**<sup>386</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_386)In fact the suggestion is preposterous. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_387"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_387"></span>**<sup>387</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_387)Umkhonto was formed by Africans to further their struggle for freedom in their own land. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_388"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_388"></span>**<sup>388</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_388)Communists and others supported the movement, and we only wish that more sections of the community would join us.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_389"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_389"></span>**<sup>389</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_389)Cuộc đấu tranh của chúng tôi chống lại những khó khăn, hay gọi theo ngôn từ của Công Tố Viện Nhà Nước “cái gọi là khó khăn”, có thật, không phải tưởng tượng. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_390"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_390"></span>**<sup>390</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_390)Cơ bản nhất, chúng tôi đấu tranh chống lại 2 điểm chính vốn là những dấu ấn của đời sống người Phi Châu ở Nam Phi và đã được củng cố bởi những quy định luật pháp mà chúng tôi tìm cách xóa bỏ. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_391"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_391"></span>**<sup>391</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_391)Hai vấn đề đó là đói nghèo và thiếu tôn trọng phẩm cách con người, and we do not need communists or so-called ‘agitators’ to teach us about these things.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_392"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_392"></span>**<sup>392</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_392)Nam Phi là nước giàu nhất ở Châu Phi, và có thể là một trong những nước giàu nhất thế giới. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_393"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_393"></span>**<sup>393</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_393)Nhưng đây cũng là mảnh đất của những sự tương phản rất lớn và lên đến cực điểm. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_394"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_394"></span>**<sup>394</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_394)Người da trắng hưởng thụ cuộc sống có thể nói là có tiêu chuẩn sống cao nhất thế giới, trong khi người Phi Châu sống trong nghèo đói và khổ sở. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_395"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_395"></span>**<sup>395</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_395)40% người Phi Châu sống trong những Khu Bảo Tồn đông nghẹt, và một số trường hợp, cực kỳ hạn hán, một cách tuyệt vọng, ở đó đất bị xói mòn và bị tận dụng kiệt cùng đến mức không có một sinh vật sống nào có thể mọc lên một cách bình thường từ đó. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_396"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_396"></span>**<sup>396</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_396)30% là người lao động tay chân, cho thuê sức lao động, và người làm công ở các trang trại của người da trắng và làm việc và sống dưới những điều kiện tương tự như của những người nông nô thời Trung Cổ. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_397"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_397"></span>**<sup>397</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_397)30% còn lại sống ở các thị trấn với những tâp quán của nền kinh tế xã hội đã phát triển giúp mang họ đến gần một số lĩnh vực trong tiêu chuẩn của người da trắng. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_398"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_398"></span>**<sup>398</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_398)Nhưng hầu hết những người Phi Châu trong nhóm này, bị bần cùng hóa vì thu nhập của họ thấp trong khi chi phí cho cuộc sống cao.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_399"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_399"></span>**<sup>399</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_399)<span style="color:#FF6600">The highest-paid and the most prosperous section of urban African life is in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_400"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_400"></span>**<sup>400</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_400)Yet their actual position is desperate. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_401"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_401"></span>**<sup>401</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_401)The latest figures were given on 25 March 1964 by Mr. Carr, Manager of the Johannesburg Non-European Affairs Department. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_402"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_402"></span>**<sup>402</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_402)The poverty datum line for the average African family in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place> (according to Mr. Carr’s department) is R42.84 per month. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_403"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_403"></span>**<sup>403</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_403)He showed that the average monthly wage is R32.24 and that 46 per cent of all African families in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place> do not earn enough to keep them going.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_404"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_404"></span>**<sup>404</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_404)Nghèo đói luôn đi kèm với suy dinh dưỡng và bệnh tật. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_405"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_405"></span>**<sup>405</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_405)Sự cố suy dinh dưỡng và bệnh tật do thiếu thốn rất cao ở người Phi Châu. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_406"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_406"></span>**<sup>406</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_406)<span style="color:#FF6600">Tuberculosis, pellagra, kwashiorkor, gastro-enteritis, and scurvy bring death and destruction of health. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_407"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_407"></span>**<sup>407</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_407)The incidence of infant mortality is one of the highest in the world. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_408"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_408"></span>**<sup>408</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_408)According to the Medical Officer of Health for <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Pretoria</st1:city></st1:place>, tuberculosis kills forty people a day (almost all Africans), and in 1961 there were 58,491 new cases reported. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_409"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_409"></span>**<sup>409</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_409)These diseases not only destroy the vital organs of the body, but they result in retarded mental conditions and lack of initiative, and reduce powers of concentration. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_410"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_410"></span>**<sup>410</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_410)The secondary results of such conditions affect the whole community and the standard of work performed by African laborers.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_411"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_411"></span>**<sup>411</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_411)Tuy nhiên, điều người Phi Châu muốn được nói đến không phải chỉ là họ nghèo và người da trắng giàu, mà còn là luật pháp do người da trắng tạo ra được thiết kế để duy trì tình trạng này. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_412"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_412"></span>**<sup>412</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_412)Có hai cách để phá vỡ tình trạng nghèo đói. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_413"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_413"></span>**<sup>413</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_413)Một là thông qua giáo dục chính thức, và cách thứ hai là bằng cách nâng cao kỹ năng cho người làm việc và nhờ vậy mức lương của họ được tăng lên. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_414"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_414"></span>**<sup>414</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_414)Đối với người Phi Châu, cả hai con đường cải thiện đời sống này đều bị cố ý tước đi mất bằng những quy định luật pháp.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_415"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_415"></span>**<sup>415</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_415)<span style="color:#FF6600">The present Government has always sought to hamper Africans in their search for education. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_416"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_416"></span>**<sup>416</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_416)One of their early acts, after coming into power, was to stop subsidies for African school feeding. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_417"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_417"></span>**<sup>417</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_417)Many African children who attended schools depended on this supplement to their diet. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_418"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_418"></span>**<sup>418</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_418)This was a cruel act.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_419"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_419"></span>**<sup>419</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_419)<span style="color:#FF6600">There is compulsory education for all white children at virtually no cost to their parents, be they rich or poor. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_420"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_420"></span>**<sup>420</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_420)Similar facilities are not provided for the African children, though there are some who receive such assistance. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_421"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_421"></span>**<sup>421</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_421)African children, however, generally have to pay more for their schooling than whites. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_422"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_422"></span>**<sup>422</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_422)According to figures quoted by the South African Institute of Race Relations in its 1963 journal, approximately 40 per cent of African children in the age group between seven to fourteen do not attend school. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_423"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_423"></span>**<sup>423</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_423)For those who do attend school, the standards are vastly different from those afforded to white children. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_424"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_424"></span>**<sup>424</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_424)In 1960-61 the per capita Government spending on African students at State-aided schools was estimated at R12.46\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_425"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_425"></span>**<sup>425</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_425)In the same years, the per capita spending on white children in the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:state w:st="on">Cape Province</st1:state></st1:place> (which are the only figures available to me) was R144.57\. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_426"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_426"></span>**<sup>426</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_426)Although there are no figures available to me, it can be stated, without doubt, that the white children on whom R144.57 per head was being spent all came from wealthier homes than African children on whom R12.46 per head was being spent.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_427"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_427"></span>**<sup>427</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_427)<span style="color:#FF6600">The quality of education is also different. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_428"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_428"></span>**<sup>428</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_428)According to the Bantu Educational Journal, only 5,660 African children in the whole of <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> passed their Junior Certificate in 1962, and in that year only 362 passed matric. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_429"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_429"></span>**<sup>429</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_429)This is presumably consistent with the policy of Bantu education about which the present Prime Minister said, during the debate on the Bantu Education Bill in 1953:</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_430"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_430"></span>**<sup>430</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_430)<span style="color:#FF6600">“When I have control of Native education I will reform it so that Natives will be taught from childhood to realize that equality with Europeans is not for them... <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_431"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_431"></span>**<sup>431</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_431)People who believe in equality are not desirable teachers for Natives. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_432"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_432"></span>**<sup>432</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_432)When my Department controls Native education it will know for what class of higher education a Native is fitted, and whether he will have a chance in life to use his knowledge.”</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_433"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_433"></span>**<sup>433</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_433)Một trở ngại chủ yếu khác khiến người Phi Châu không cải thiện kinh tế được là cản trở màu da trong hoạt động công nghiệp, theo đó tất cả các việc làm tốt trong các ngành công nghiệp đều chỉ được dành riêng cho người Da Trắng. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_434"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_434"></span>**<sup>434</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_434)Hơn thế nữa, những người Phi Châu tìm được việc làm với những nghề nghiệp từ không chuyên môn cho đến bán chuyên môn không được phép tổ chức công đoàn được công nhận theo Luật Hòa Giải Công nghiệp. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_435"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_435"></span>**<sup>435</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_435)Điều này có nghĩa là mọi cuộc biểu tình của công nhân người Phi Châu là bất hợp pháp, và họ bị phủ nhận quyền thương thảo lương, quyền mà công nhân Da Trắng được trả lương cao hơn được cho phép. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_436"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_436"></span>**<sup>436</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_436)<span style="color:#FF6600">The discrimination in the policy of successive South African Governments towards African workers is demonstrated by the so-called ‘civilized labor policy’ under which sheltered, unskilled Government jobs are found for those white workers who cannot make the grade in industry, at wages which far exceed the earnings of the average African employee in industry.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_437"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_437"></span>**<sup>437</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_437)<span style="color:#FF6600">The Government often answers its critics by saying that Africans in <st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region> are economically better off than the inhabitants of the other countries in <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_438"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_438"></span>**<sup>438</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_438)I do not know whether this statement is true and doubt whether any comparison can be made without having regard to the cost-of-living index in such countries. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_439"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_439"></span>**<sup>439</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_439)But even if it is true, as far as the African people are concerned it is irrelevant. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_440"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_440"></span>**<sup>440</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_440)Our complaint is not that we are poor by comparison with people in other countries, but that we are poor by comparison with the white people in our own country, and that we are prevented by legislation from altering this imbalance.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_441"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_441"></span>**<sup>441</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_441)Sự thiếu tôn trọng phẩm cách con người mà người Phi Châu phải trải qua là hệ quả trực tiếp của chính sách da trắng thượng đẳng. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_442"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_442"></span>**<sup>442</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_442)Da trắng thượng đẳng nghĩa là ám chỉ người da đen là hạ cấp. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_443"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_443"></span>**<sup>443</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_443)Luật pháp được thiết kế để duy trì quyền thượng đẳng của người da trắng giúp củng cố ý niệm này. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_444"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_444"></span>**<sup>444</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_444)<span style="color:#FF6600">Menial tasks in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> are invariably performed by Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_445"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_445"></span>**<sup>445</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_445)When anything has to be carried or cleaned the white man will look around for an African to do it for him, whether the African is employed by him or not. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_446"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_446"></span>**<sup>446</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_446)Because of this sort of attitude, whites tend to regard Africans as a separate breed. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_447"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_447"></span>**<sup>447</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_447)They do not look upon them as people with families of their own; they do not realize that they have emotions – that they fall in love like white people do; that they want to be with their wives and children like white people want to be with theirs; that they want to earn enough money to support their families properly, to feed and clothe them and send them to school. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_448"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_448"></span>**<sup>448</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_448)And what ‘house-boy’ or ‘garden-boy’ or laborer can ever hope to do this?</span> <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_449"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_449"></span>**<sup>449</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_449)Luật lưu hành, đối với người Phi Châu là một trong những những quy định luật bị ghét nhất ở Nam Phi, cho phép cảnh sát được quyền theo dõi người Phi Châu bất cứ lúc nào. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_450"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_450"></span>**<sup>450</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_450)Tôi không tin là có được một người đàn ông Phi Châu nào ở Nam Phi trong đời chưa bao giờ đụng chạm với cảnh sát trong lúc đi lại. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_451"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_451"></span>**<sup>451</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_451)Hàng trăm và hàng ngàn người Phi Châu bị ném vào nhà giam mỗi năm vì các quy định luật lưu hành. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_452"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_452"></span>**<sup>452</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_452)Còn tệ hơn nữa, đây là sự thật, luật lưu hành đó phân cách chồng và vợ và khiến phá vỡ cuộc sống gia đình.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_453"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_453"></span>**<sup>453</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_453)Nghèo đói và gia đình tan vỡ gây ra những ảnh hưởng liên đới khác. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_454"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_454"></span>**<sup>454</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_454)Trẻ em lang thang trên đường phố các thị trấn bởi vì các em không có trường để đi học, hoặc không có tiền để có thể đến trường, hoặc không có Cha Mẹ ở nhà để đảm bảo các em đi học, bởi vì cả Cha lẫn Mẹ (nếu như có cả Cha Mẹ) phải đi làm để nuôi sống cả gia đình. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_455"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_455"></span>**<sup>455</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_455)Điều này dẫn đến phá vỡ các chuẩn mực đạo đức, tăng một cách đáng báo động trường hợp có con hoang, và tình trạng gia tăng bao lực bùng nổ không chỉ trong chính trị, mà ở tất cả mọi nơi. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_456"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_456"></span>**<sup>456</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_456)Cuộc sống ở các thị trấn rất nguy hiểm. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_457"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_457"></span>**<sup>457</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_457)<span style="color:#FF6600">There is not a day that goes by without somebody being stabbed or assaulted. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_458"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_458"></span>**<sup>458</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_458)And violence is carried out of the townships in the white living areas. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_459"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_459"></span>**<sup>459</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_459)People are afraid to walk alone in the streets after dark. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_460"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_460"></span>**<sup>460</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_460)Housebreakings and robberies are increasing, despite the fact that the death sentence can now be imposed for such offences. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_461"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_461"></span>**<sup>461</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_461)Death sentences cannot cure the festering sore.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_462"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_462"></span>**<sup>462</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_462)Người Phi Châu muốn được trả lương đủ sống. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_463"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_463"></span>**<sup>463</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_463)Người Phi Châu muốn làm việc mà họ đủ sức để làm, chứ không phải làm việc mà Nhà Nước cho rằng họ đủ khả năng để làm. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_464"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_464"></span>**<sup>464</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_464)Người Phi Châu muốn được phép sống ở bất cứ đâu họ có thể tìm được việc làm, mà không phải được cho phép mới ra khỏi một khu vực vì họ không sinh ra ở đó. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_465"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_465"></span>**<sup>465</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_465)Người Phi Châu muốn được cho phép sở hữu đất đai mà họ làm việc trên đó, mà không phải được gia ơn sống trong nhà thuê mà không bao giờ họ được gọi là nhà mình. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_466"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_466"></span>**<sup>466</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_466)Người Phi Châu muốn là một phần của dân số nói chung, mà không phải bị giới hạn sống trong những khu ổ chuột của họ. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_467"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_467"></span>**<sup>467</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_467)Người đàn ông Phi Châu muốn vợ và các con sống cùng với họ ở nơi họ làm việc, mà không phải bị ép vào sống một cách thiếu tự nhiên trong các nhà ở dành riêng cho nam. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_468"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_468"></span>**<sup>468</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_468)Người phụ nữ Phi Châu muốn được ở cùng với người đàn ông thân thuộc mà không bị bỏ rơi thường trực như quả phụ ở các Khu Bảo Tồn. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_469"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_469"></span>**<sup>469</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_469)Người Phi Châu muốn được cho phép ra ngoài sau 11h đêm và không bị nhốt trong phòng của họ như những đứa trẻ con. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_470"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_470"></span>**<sup>470</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_470)Người Phi Châu muốn được phép đi lại trong đất nước của họ và tìm việc làm ở nơi họ muốn chứ không phải ở nơi Phòng Lao động bảo họ đến. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_471"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_471"></span>**<sup>471</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_471)Người Phi Châu muốn một phần công chính trong toàn bộ Nam Phi; họ muốn an ninh và một phần sở hữu trong xã hội.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_472"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_472"></span>**<sup>472</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_472)Trên tất cả, chúng tôi muốn các quyền bình đẳng về chính trị, bởi vì không có nó, những thiệt thòi của chúng tôi sẽ trở thành vĩnh viễn. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_473"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_473"></span>**<sup>473</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_473)Tôi biết điều này nghe rất cách mạng đối với những người da trắng trong đất nước này bởi vì khi đó đa số người đi bỏ phiếu bầu cử sẽ là người Phi Châu. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_474"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_474"></span>**<sup>474</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_474)Nó sẽ khiến người da trắng sợ hãi nền dân chủ.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_475"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_475"></span>**<sup>475</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_475)Nhưng sợ hãi này không thể được cho phép nằm ngáng đường cản trở giải pháp duy nhất giúp đảm bảo sự hòa hợp chủng tộc và tự do cho tất cả mọi người. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_476"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_476"></span>**<sup>476</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_476)Sự ban quyền bầu cử cho tất cả mọi người sẽ đem lại sự thống trị của một vài chủng tộc là không đúng. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_477"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_477"></span>**<sup>477</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_477)Sự phân chia về chính trị, dựa trên màu da, là hoàn toàn không tự nhiên và khi nó biến mất, sự thống trị của một nhóm màu da trên một nhóm khác cũng sẽ biến mất. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_478"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_478"></span>**<sup>478</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_478)The ANC has spent half a century fighting against racialism. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_479"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_479"></span>**<sup>479</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_479)When it triumphs it will not change that policy.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_480"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_480"></span>**<sup>480</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_480)This then is what the ANC is fighting. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_481"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_481"></span>**<sup>481</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_481)Their struggle is a truly national one. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_482"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_482"></span>**<sup>482</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_482)It is a struggle of the African people, inspired by their own suffering and their own experience. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_483"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_483"></span>**<sup>483</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_483)It is a struggle for the right to live.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_484"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_484"></span>**<sup>484</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_484)Trong suốt cuộc đời tôi, tôi hiến dâng chính mình cho cuộc đấu tranh này của nhân dân Phi Châu. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_485"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_485"></span>**<sup>485</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_485)Tôi đã chiến đấu chống lại sự thống trị của người da trắng, và tôi đã chiến đấu chống lại sự thống trị của người da đen. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_486"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_486"></span>**<sup>486</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_486)Tôi đã ấp ủ trong lòng lý tưởng của một xã hội tự do và dân chủ ở đó tất cả mọi người sống hòa hợp với nhau và có những cơ hội bình đẳng như nhau. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_487"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_487"></span>**<sup>487</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_487)Đây là lý tưởng mà tôi hy vọng sống cho nó và đạt được nó. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_488"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_488"></span>**<sup>488</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_488)Nhưng nếu cần, đây là lý tưởng mà vì nó tôi sẵn sàng để chết.

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_489"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_489"></span>**<sup>489</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_489)Nelson Mandela – Ngày 20 Tháng 04 Năm 1964.

_(Hồng Quyên dịch)_

(Translated excerpts in red)

<a name="E_dienvan_v_22_490"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_490"></span>**<sup>490</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_490)<span style="color:#FF6600">Post-note: On June 11, 1964, at the conclusion of the trial, Mandela was found guilty on four charges of sabotage and was sentenced to life imprisonment. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_491"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_491"></span>**<sup>491</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_491)He began his sentence in the notorious Robben Island Prison, a maximum security prison on a small island off the coast near <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Cape Town</st1:city></st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_492"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_492"></span>**<sup>492</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_492)A worldwide campaign to free Mandela began in the 1980s and resulted in his release on February 11, 1990, at age 71, after 27 years in prison. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_493"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_493"></span>**<sup>493</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_493)In 1993, Mandela shared the Nobel Peace Prize with <st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region>’s President F.W. de Klerk for their peaceful efforts to bring a non-racial democracy to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_v_22_494"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_v_22_494"></span>**<sup>494</sup>**](#E_dienvan_e_22_494)Black South Africans voted for the first time in the 1994 election that brought Mandela the presidency of <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>.</span>

**I am the First Accused.**

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_1"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_1"></span>**<sup>1</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_1)<span style="color:#FF6600">I hold a Bachelor’s Degree in Arts and practised as an attorney in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place> for a number of years in partnership with Oliver Tambo. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_2"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_2"></span>**<sup>2</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_2)I am a convicted prisoner serving five years for leaving the country without a permit and for inciting people to go on strike at the end of May 1961.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_3"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_3"></span>**<sup>3</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_3)At the outset, I want to say that the suggestion made by the State in its opening that the struggle in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> is under the influence of foreigners or communists is wholly incorrect. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_4"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_4"></span>**<sup>4</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_4)I have done whatever I did, both as an individual and as a leader of my people, because of my experience in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> and my own proudly felt African background, and not because of what any outsider might have said.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_5"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_5"></span>**<sup>5</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_5)<span style="color:#FF6600">In my youth in the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Transkei</st1:country-region></st1:place> I listened to the elders of my tribe telling stories of the old days. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_6"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:
E_dienvan_e_22_6"></span>**<sup>6</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_6)Amongst the tales they related to me were those of wars fought by our ancestors in defence of the fatherland. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_7"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_7"></span>**<sup>7</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_7)The names of Dingane and Bambata, Hintsa and Makana, Squngthi and Dalasile, Moshoeshoe and Sekhukhuni, were praised as the glory of the entire African nation. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_8"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:
E_dienvan_e_22_8"></span>**<sup>8</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_8)I hoped then that life might offer me the opportunity to serve my people and make my own humble contribution to their freedom struggle. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_9"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_9"></span>**<sup>9</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_9)This is what has motivated me in all that I have done in relation to the charges made against me in this case.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_10"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_10"></span>**<sup>10</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_10)<span style="color:#FF6600">Having said this, I must deal immediately and at some length with the question of violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_11"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_11"></span>**<sup>11</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_11)Some of the things so far told to the Court are true and some are untrue. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_12"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_12"></span>**<sup>12</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_12)I do not, however, deny that I planned sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_13"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_13"></span>**<sup>13</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_13)I did not plan it in a spirit of recklessness, nor because I have any love of violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_14"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_14"></span>**<sup>14</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_14)I planned it as a result of a calm and sober assessment of the political situation that had arisen after many years of tyranny, exploitation, and oppression of my people by the Whites.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_15"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_15"></span>**<sup>15</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_15)<span style="color:#FF6600">I admit immediately that I was one of the persons who helped to form Umkhonto we Sizwe, and that I played a prominent role in its affairs until I was arrested in August 1962.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_16"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_16"></span>**<sup>16</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_16)<span style="color:#FF6600">In the statement which I am about to make I shall correct certain false impressions which have been created by State witnesses. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_17"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_17"></span>**<sup>17</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_17)Amongst other things, I will demonstrate that certain of the acts referred to in the evidence were not and could not have been committed by Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_18"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_18"></span>**<sup>18</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_18)I will also deal with the relationship between the African National Congress and Umkhonto, and with the part which I personally have played in the affairs of both organizations. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_19"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_19"></span>**<sup>19</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_19)I shall deal also with the part played by the Communist Party. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_20"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_20"></span>**<sup>20</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_20)In order to explain these matters properly, I will have to explain what Umkhonto set out to achieve; what methods it prescribed for the achievement of these objects, and why these methods were chosen. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_21"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_21"></span>**<sup>21</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_21)I will also have to explain how I became involved in the activities of these organizations.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_22"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_22"></span>**<sup>22</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_22)<span style="color:#FF6600">I deny that Umkhonto was responsible for a number of acts which clearly fell outside the policy of the organization, and which have been charged in the indictment against us. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_23"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_23"></span>**<sup>23</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_23)I do not know what justification there was for these acts, but to demonstrate that they could not have been authorized by Umkhonto, I want to refer briefly to the roots and policy of the organization.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_24"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_24"></span>**<sup>24</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_24)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have already mentioned that I was one of the persons who helped to form Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_25"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_25"></span>**<sup>25</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_25)I, and the others who started the organization, did so for two reasons.</span> <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_26"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_26"></span>**<sup>26</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_26)Firstly, we believed that as a result of Government policy, violence by the African people had become inevitable, and that unless responsible leadership was given to canalize and control the feelings of our people, there would be outbreaks of terrorism which would produce an intensity of bitterness and hostility between the various races of this country which is not produced even by war. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_27"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_27"></span>**<sup>27</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_27)Secondly, we felt that without violence there would be no way open to the African people to succeed in their struggle against the principle of white supremacy. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_28"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_28"></span>**<sup>28</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_28)All lawful modes of expressing opposition to this principle had been closed by legislation, and we were placed in a position in which we had either to accept a permanent state of inferiority, or to defy the Government. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_29"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_29"></span>**<sup>29</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_29)We chose to defy the law. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_30"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_30"></span>**<sup>30</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_30)We first broke the law in a way which avoided any recourse to violence; when this form was legislated against, and then the Government resorted to a show of force to crush opposition to its policies, only then did we decide to answer violence with violence.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_31"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_31"></span>**<sup>31</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_31)But the violence which we chose to adopt was not terrorism. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_32"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_32"></span>**<sup>32</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_32)We who formed Umkhonto were all members of the African National Congress, and had behind us the ANC tradition of non-violence and negotiation as a means of solving political disputes. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_33"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_33"></span>**<sup>33</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_33)<span style="color:#FF6600">We believe that <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> belongs to all the people who live in it, and not to one group, be it black or white. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_34"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_34"></span>**<sup>34</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_34)We did not want an interracial war, and tried to avoid it to the last minute. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_35"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_35"></span>**<sup>35</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_35)If the Court is in doubt about this, it will be seen that the whole history of our organization bears out what I have said, and what I will subsequently say, when I describe the tactics which Umkhonto decided to adopt. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_36"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_36"></span>**<sup>36</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_36)I want, therefore, to say something about the African National Congress.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_37"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_37"></span>**<sup>37</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_37)<span style="color:#FF6600">The African National Congress was formed in 1912 to defend the rights of the African people which had been seriously curtailed by the South Africa Act, and which were then being threatened by the Native Land Act. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_38"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_38"></span>**<sup>38</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_38)For thirty-seven years – that is until 1949 – it adhered strictly to a constitutional struggle. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_39"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_39"></span>**<sup>39</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_39)It put forward demands and resolutions; it sent delegations to the Government in the belief that African grievances could be settled through peaceful discussion and that Africans could advance gradually to full political rights. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_40"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_40"></span>**<sup>40</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_40)But White Governments remained unmoved, and the rights of Africans became less instead of becoming greater.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_41"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_41"></span>**<sup>41</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_41)In the words of my leader, Chief Lutuli, who became President of the ANC in 1952, and who was later awarded the Nobel Peace Prize:

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_42"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_42"></span>**<sup>42</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_42)“Who will deny that thirty years of my life have been spent knocking in vain, patiently, moderately, and modestly at a closed and barred door? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_43"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_43"></span>**<sup>43</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_43)What have been the fruits of moderation? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_44"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_44"></span>**<sup>44</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_44)The past thirty years have seen the greatest number of laws restricting our rights and progress, until today we have reached a stage where we have almost no rights at all.”

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_45"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_45"></span>**<sup>45</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_45)<span style="color:#FF6600">Even after 1949, the ANC remained determined to avoid violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_46"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_46"></span>**<sup>46</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_46)At this time, however, there was a change from the strictly constitutional means of protest which had been employed in the past. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_47"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_47"></span>**<sup>47</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_47)The change was embodied in a decision which was taken to protest against apartheid legislation by peaceful, but unlawful, demonstrations against certain laws. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_48"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_48"></span>**<sup>48</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_48)Pursuant to this policy the ANC launched the Defiance Campaign, in which I was placed in charge of volunteers. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_49"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_49"></span>**<sup>49</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_49)This campaign was based on the principles of passive resistance. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_50"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_50"></span>**<sup>50</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_50)More than 8,500 people defied apartheid laws and went to jail. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_51"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_51"></span>**<sup>51</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_51)Yet there was not a single instance of violence in the course of this campaign on the part of any defier. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_52"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_52"></span>**<sup>52</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_52)I and nineteen colleagues were convicted for the role which we played in organizing the campaign, but our sentences were suspended mainly because the Judge found that discipline and non-violence had been stressed throughout. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_53"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_53"></span>**<sup>53</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_53)This was the time when the volunteer section of the ANC was established, and when the word ‘Amadelakufa’ was first used: this was the time when the volunteers were asked to take a pledge to uphold certain principles. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_54"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_54"></span>**<sup>54</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_54)Evidence dealing with volunteers and their pledges has been introduced into this case, but completely out of context. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_55"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_55"></span>**<sup>55</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_55)The volunteers were not, and are not, the soldiers of a black army pledged to fight a civil war against the whites. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_56"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_56"></span>**<sup>56</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_56)They were, and are, dedicated workers who are prepared to lead campaigns initiated by the ANC to distribute leaflets, to organize strikes, or do whatever the particular campaign required. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_57"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_57"></span>**<sup>57</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_57)They are called volunteers because they volunteer to face the penalties of imprisonment and whipping which are now prescribed by the legislature for such acts.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_58"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_58"></span>**<sup>58</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_58)<span style="color:#FF6600">During the <st1:city w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Defiance</st1:place></st1:city> Campaign, the Public Safety Act and the Criminal Law Amendment Act were passed. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_59"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_59"></span>**<sup>59</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_59)These Statutes provided harsher penalties for offences committed by way of protests against laws. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_60"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_60"></span>**<sup>60</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_60)Despite this, the protests continued and the ANC adhered to its policy of non-violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_61"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_61"></span>**<sup>61</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_61)In 1956, 156 leading members of the Congress Alliance, including myself, were arrested on a charge of high treason and charges under the Suppression of Communism Act.  
<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_62"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_62"></span>**<sup>62</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_62)The non-violent policy of the ANC was put in issue by the State, but when the Court gave judgement some five years later, it found that the ANC did not have a policy of violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_63"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_63"></span>**<sup>63</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_63)We were acquitted on all counts, which included a count that the ANC sought to set up a communist state in place of the existing regime. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_64"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_64"></span>**<sup>64</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_64)The Government has always sought to label all its opponents as communists. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_65"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_65"></span>**<sup>65</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_65)This allegation has been repeated in the present case, but as I will show, the ANC is not, and never has been, a communist organization.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_66"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_66"></span>**<sup>66</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_66)<span style="color:#FF6600">In 1960 there was the shooting at Sharpeville, which resulted in the proclamation of a state of emergency and the declaration of the ANC as an unlawful organization. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_67"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_67"></span>**<sup>67</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_67)My colleagues and I, after careful consideration, decided that we would not obey this decree. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_68"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_68"></span>**<sup>68</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_68)The African people were not part of the Government and did not make the laws by which they were governed. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_69"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_69"></span>**<sup>69</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_69)We believed in the words of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, that ‘the will of the people shall be the basis of authority of the Government,’ and for us to accept the banning was equivalent to accepting the silencing of the Africans for all time. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_70"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_70"></span>**<sup>70</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_70)The ANC refused to dissolve, but instead went underground. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_71"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_71"></span>**<sup>71</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_71)We believed it was our duty to preserve this organization which had been built up with almost fifty years of unremitting toil. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_72"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_72"></span>**<sup>72</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_72)I have no doubt that no self-respecting White political organization would disband itself if declared illegal by a government in which it had no say.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_73"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_73"></span>**<sup>73</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_73)In 1960 the Government held a referendum which led to the establishment of the Republic. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_74"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_74"></span>**<sup>74</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_74)Africans, who constituted approximately 70 per cent of the population of <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>, were not entitled to vote, and were not even consulted about the proposed constitutional change. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_75"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_75"></span>**<sup>75</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_75)All of us were apprehensive of our future under the proposed <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:placename w:st="on">White</st1:placename> <st1:placetype w:st="on">Republic</st1:placetype></st1:place>, and a resolution was taken to hold an All-In African Conference to call for a National Convention, and to organize mass demonstrations on the eve of the unwanted Republic, if the Government failed to call the Convention. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_76"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_76"></span>**<sup>76</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_76)<span style="color:#FF6600">The conference was attended by Africans of various political persuasions. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_77"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_77"></span>**<sup>77</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_77)I was the Secretary of the conference and undertook to be responsible for organizing the national stay-at-home which was subsequently called to coincide with the declaration of the Republic.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_78"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_78"></span>**<sup>78</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_78)As all strikes by Africans are illegal, the person organizing such a strike must avoid arrest. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_79"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_79"></span>**<sup>79</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_79)I was chosen to be this person, and consequently I had to leave my home and family and my practice and go into hiding to avoid arrest.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_80"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_80"></span>**<sup>80</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_80)<span style="color:#FF6600">The stay-at-home, in accordance with ANC policy, was to be a peaceful demonstration. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_81"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_81"></span>**<sup>81</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_81)Careful instructions were given to organizers and members to avoid any recourse to violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_82"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_82"></span>**<sup>82</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_82)The Government’s answer was to introduce new and harsher laws, to mobilize its armed forces, and to send Saracens, armed vehicles, and soldiers into the townships in a massive show of force designed to intimidate the people. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_83"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_83"></span>**<sup>83</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_83)This was an indication that the Government had decided to rule by force alone, and this decision was a milestone on the road to Umkhonto.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_84"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_84"></span>**<sup>84</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_84)<span style="color:#FF6600">Some of this may appear irrelevant to this trial. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_85"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_85"></span>**<sup>85</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_85)In fact, I believe none of it is irrelevant because it will, I hope, enable the Court to appreciate the attitude eventually adopted by the various persons and bodies concerned in the National Liberation Movement. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_86"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_86"></span>**<sup>86</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_86)When I went to jail in 1962, the dominant idea was that loss of life should be avoided. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_87"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_87"></span>**<sup>87</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_87)I now know that this was still so in 1963.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_88"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_88"></span>**<sup>88</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_88)I must return to June 1961\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_89"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_89"></span>**<sup>89</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_89)What were we, the leaders of our people, to do? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_90"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_90"></span>**<sup>90</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_90)Were we to give in to the show of force and the implied threat against future action, or were we to fight it and, if so, how?

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_91"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_91"></span>**<sup>91</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_91)<span style="color:#FF6600">We had no doubt that we had to continue the fight. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_92"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_92"></span>**<sup>92</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_92)Anything else would have been abject surrender. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_93"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_93"></span>**<sup>93</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_93)Our problem was not whether to fight, but was how to continue the fight. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_94"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_94"></span>**<sup>94</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_94)We of the ANC had always stood for a non-racial democracy, and we shrank from any action which might drive the races further apart than they already were.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_95"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_95"></span>**<sup>95</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_95)<span style="color:#FF6600">But the hard facts were that fifty years of non-violence had brought the African people nothing but more and more repressive legislation, and fewer and fewer rights. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_96"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_96"></span>**<sup>96</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_96)It may not be easy for this Court to understand, but it is a fact that for a long time the people had been talking of violence – of the day when they would fight the White man and win back their country – and we, the leaders of the ANC, had nevertheless always prevailed upon them to avoid violence and to pursue peaceful methods. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_97"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_97"></span>**<sup>97</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_97)When some of us discussed this in May and June of 1961, it could not be denied that our policy to achieve a non-racial State by non-violence had achieved nothing, and that our followers were beginning to lose confidence in this policy and were developing disturbing ideas of terrorism.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_98"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_98"></span>**<sup>98</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_98)It must not be forgotten that by this time violence had, in fact, become a feature of the South African political scene. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_99"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_99"></span>**<sup>99</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_99)There had been violence in 1957 when the women of Zeerust were ordered to carry passes; there was violence in 1958 with the enforcement of cattle culling in Sekhukhuniland; there was violence in 1959 when the people of Cato Manor protested against pass raids; there was violence in 1960 when the Government attempted to impose Bantu Authorities in Pondoland. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_100"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_100"></span>**<sup>100</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_100)Thirty-nine Africans died in these disturbances. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_101"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_101"></span>**<sup>101</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_101)In 1961 there had been riots in Warmbaths, and all this time the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Transkei</st1:country-region></st1:place> had been a seething mass of unrest. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_102"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_102"></span>**<sup>102</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_102)Each disturbance pointed clearly to the inevitable growth among Africans of the belief that violence was the only way out – it showed that a Government which uses force to maintain its rule teaches the oppressed to use force to oppose it.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_103"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_103"></span>**<sup>103</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_103)<span style="color:#FF6600">Already small groups had arisen in the urban areas and were spontaneously making plans for violent forms of political struggle. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_104"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_104"></span>**<sup>104</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_104)There now arose a danger that these groups would adopt terrorism against Africans, as well as Whites, if not properly directed. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_105"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_105"></span>**<sup>105</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_105)Particularly disturbing was the type of violence engendered in places such as Zeerust, Sekhukhuniland, and Pondoland amongst Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_106"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_106"></span>**<sup>106</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_106)It was increasingly taking the form, not of struggle against the Government – though this is what prompted it – but of civil strife amongst themselves, conducted in such a way that it could not hope to achieve anything other than a loss of life and bitterness.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_107"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_107"></span>**<sup>107</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_107)At the beginning of June 1961, after a long and anxious assessment of the South African situation, I, and some colleagues, came to the conclusion that as violence in this country was inevitable, it would be unrealistic and wrong for African leaders to continue preaching peace and non-violence at a time when the Government met our peaceful demands with force.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_108"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_108"></span>**<sup>108</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_108)<span style="color:#FF6600">This conclusion was not easily arrived at. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_109"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_109"></span>**<sup>109</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_109)It was only when all else had failed, when all channels of peaceful protest had been barred to us, that the decision was made to embark on violent forms of political struggle, and to form Umkhonto we Sizwe. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_110"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_110"></span>**<sup>110</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_110)We did so not because we desired such a course, but solely because the Government had left us with no other choice. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_111"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_111"></span>**<sup>111</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_111)In the Manifesto of Umkhonto published on 16 December 1961, which is Exhibit AD, we said: “The time comes in the life of any nation when there remain only two choices – submit or fight. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_112"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_112"></span>**<sup>112</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_112)That time has now come to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_113"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_113"></span>**<sup>113</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_113)We shall not submit and we have no choice but to hit back by all means in our power in defence of our people, our future, and our freedom.”</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_114"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_114"></span>**<sup>114</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_114)<span style="color:#FF6600">This was our feeling in June of 1961 when we decided to press for a change in the policy of the National Liberation Movement. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_115"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_115"></span>**<sup>115</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_115)I can only say that I felt morally obliged to do what I did.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_116"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_116"></span>**<sup>116</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_116)<span style="color:#FF6600">We who had taken this decision started to consult leaders of various organizations, including the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_117"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_117"></span>**<sup>117</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_117)I will not say whom we spoke to, or what they said, but I wish to deal with the role of the African National Congress in this phase of the struggle, and with the policy and objectives of Umkhonto we Sizwe.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_118"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_118"></span>**<sup>118</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_118)<span style="color:#FF6600">As far as the ANC was concerned, it formed a clear view which can be summarized as follows:</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_119"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_119"></span>**<sup>119</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_119)<span style="color:#FF6600">• It was a mass political organization with a political function to fulfil. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_120"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_120"></span>**<sup>120</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_120)Its members had joined on the express policy of non-violence.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_121"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_121"></span>**<sup>121</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_121)<span style="color:#FF6600">• Because of all this, it could not and would not undertake violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_122"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_122"></span>**<sup>122</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_122)This must be stressed. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_123"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_123"></span>**<sup>123</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_123)One cannot turn such a body into the small, closely knit organization required for sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_124"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_124"></span>**<sup>124</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_124)Nor would this be politically correct, because it would result in members ceasing to carry out this essential activity: political propaganda and organization. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_125"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_125"></span>**<sup>125</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_125)Nor was it permissible to change the whole nature of the organization.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_126"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_126"></span>**<sup>126</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_126)<span style="color:#FF6600">• On the other hand, in view of this situation I have described, the ANC was prepared to depart from its fifty-year-old policy of non-violence to this extent that it would no longer disapprove of properly controlled violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_127"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_127"></span>**<sup>127</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_127)Hence members who undertook such activity would not be subject to disciplinary action by the ANC.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_128"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_128"></span>**<sup>128</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_128)<span style="color:#FF6600">I say ‘properly controlled violence’ because I made it clear that if I formed the organization I would at all times subject it to the political guidance of the ANC and would not undertake any different form of activity from that contemplated without the consent of the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_129"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_129"></span>**<sup>129</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_129)And I shall now tell the Court how that form of violence came to be determined.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_130"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_130"></span>**<sup>130</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_130)<span style="color:#FF6600">As a result of this decision, Umkhonto was formed in November 1961\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_131"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_131"></span>**<sup>131</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_131)When we took this decision, and subsequently formulated our plans, the ANC heritage of non-violence and racial harmony was very much with us. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_132"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_132"></span>**<sup>132</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_132)We felt that the country was drifting towards a civil war in which Blacks and Whites would fight each other. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_133"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_133"></span>**<sup>133</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_133)We viewed the situation with alarm. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_134"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_134"></span>**<sup>134</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_134)Civil war could mean the destruction of what the ANC stood for; with civil war, racial peace would be more difficult than ever to achieve. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_135"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_135"></span>**<sup>135</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_135)We already have examples in South African history of the results of war. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_136"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_136"></span>**<sup>136</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_136)It has taken more than fifty years for the scars of the South African War to disappear. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_137"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_137"></span>**<sup>137</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_137)How much longer would it take to eradicate the scars of inter-racial civil war, which could not be fought without a great loss of life on both sides?</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_138"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_138"></span>**<sup>138</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_138)<span style="color:#FF6600">The avoidance of civil war had dominated our thinking for many years, but when we decided to adopt violence as part of our policy, we realized that we might one day have to face the prospect of such a war. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_139"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_139"></span>**<sup>139</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_139)This had to be taken into account in formulating our plans. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_140"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_140"></span>**<sup>140</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_140)We required a plan which was flexible and which permitted us to act in accordance with the needs of the times; above all, the plan had to be one which recognized civil war as the last resort, and left the decision on this question to the future. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_141"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_141"></span>**<sup>141</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_141)We did not want to be committed to civil war, but we wanted to be ready if it became inevitable.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_142"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_142"></span>**<sup>142</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_142)<span style="color:#FF6600">Four forms of violence were possible. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_143"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_143"></span>**<sup>143</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_143)There is sabotage, there is guerrilla warfare, there is terrorism, and there is open revolution. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_144"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_144"></span>**<sup>144</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_144)We chose to adopt the first method and to exhaust it before taking any other decision.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_145"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_145"></span>**<sup>145</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_145)<span style="color:#FF6600">In the light of our political background the choice was a logical one. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_146"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_146"></span>**<sup>146</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_146)Sabotage did not involve loss of life, and it offered the best hope for future race relations. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_147"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_147"></span>**<sup>147</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_147)Bitterness would be kept to a minimum and, if the policy bore fruit, democratic government could become a reality. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_148"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_148"></span>**<sup>148</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_148)This is what we felt at the time, and this is what we said in our Manifesto (Exhibit AD):</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_149"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_149"></span>**<sup>149</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_149)<span style="color:#FF6600">“We of Umkhonto we Sizwe have always sought to achieve liberation without bloodshed and civil clash. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_150"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_150"></span>**<sup>150</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_150)We hope, even at this late hour, that our first actions will awaken everyone to a realization of the disastrous situation to which the Nationalist policy is leading. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_151"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_151"></span>**<sup>151</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_151)We hope that we will bring the Government and its supporters to their senses before it is too late, so that both the Government and its policies can be changed before matters reach the desperate state of civil war.”</span>
