<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_152"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_152"></span>**<sup>152</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_152)<span style="color:#FF6600">The initial plan was based on a careful analysis of the political and economic situation of our country. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_153"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_153"></span>**<sup>153</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_153)We believed that <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> depended to a large extent on foreign capital and foreign trade. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_154"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_154"></span>**<sup>154</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_154)We felt that planned destruction of power plants, and interference with rail and telephone communications, would tend to scare away capital from the country, make it more difficult for goods from the industrial areas to reach the seaports on schedule, and would in the long run be a heavy drain on the economic life of the country, thus compelling the voters of the country to reconsider their position.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_155"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_155"></span>**<sup>155</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_155)<span style="color:#FF6600">Attacks on the economic life-lines of the country were to be linked with sabotage on Government buildings and other symbols of apartheid. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_156"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_156"></span>**<sup>156</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_156)These attacks would serve as a source of inspiration to our people. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_157"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_157"></span>**<sup>157</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_157)In addition, they would provide an outlet for those people who were urging the adoption of violent methods and would enable us to give concrete proof to our followers that we had adopted a stronger line and were fighting back against Government violence.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_158"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_158"></span>**<sup>158</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_158)<span style="color:#FF6600">In addition, if mass action were successfully organized, and mass reprisals taken, we felt that sympathy for our cause would be roused in other countries, and that greater pressure would be brought to bear on the South African Government.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_159"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_159"></span>**<sup>159</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_159)<span style="color:#FF6600">This then was the plan. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_160"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_160"></span>**<sup>160</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_160)Umkhonto was to perform sabotage, and strict instructions were given to its members right from the start, that on no account were they to injure or kill people in planning or carrying out operations. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_161"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_161"></span>**<sup>161</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_161)These instructions have been referred to in the evidence of ‘Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_162"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_162"></span>**<sup>162</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_162)X’ and ‘Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_163"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_163"></span>**<sup>163</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_163)Z.’</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_164"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_164"></span>**<sup>164</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_164)<span style="color:#FF6600">The affairs of the Umkhonto were controlled and directed by a National High Command, which had powers of co-option and which could, and did, appoint Regional Commands. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_165"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_165"></span>**<sup>165</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_165)The High Command was the body which determined tactics and targets and was in charge of training and finance. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_166"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_166"></span>**<sup>166</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_166)Under the High Command there were Regional Commands which were responsible for the direction of the local sabotage groups. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_167"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_167"></span>**<sup>167</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_167)Within the framework of the policy laid down by the National High Command, the Regional Commands had authority to select the targets to be attacked. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_168"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_168"></span>**<sup>168</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_168)They had no authority to go beyond the prescribed framework and thus had no authority to embark upon acts which endangered life, or which did not fit into the overall plan of sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_169"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_169"></span>**<sup>169</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_169)For instance, Umkhonto members were forbidden ever to go armed into operation. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_170"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_170"></span>**<sup>170</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_170)Incidentally, the terms High Command and Regional Command were an importation from the Jewish national underground organization Irgun Zvai Leumi, which operated in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Israel</st1:country-region></st1:place> between 1944 and 1948.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_171"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_171"></span>**<sup>171</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_171)<span style="color:#FF6600">Umkhonto had its first operation on 16 December 1961, when Government buildings in <st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city>, <st1:city w:st="on">Port Elizabeth</st1:city> and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Durban</st1:city></st1:place> were attacked. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_172"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_172"></span>**<sup>172</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_172)The selection of targets is proof of the policy to which I have referred. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_173"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_173"></span>**<sup>173</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_173)Had we intended to attack life we would have selected targets where people congregated and not empty buildings and power stations. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_174"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_174"></span>**<sup>174</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_174)The sabotage which was committed before 16 December 1961 was the work of isolated groups and had no connection whatever with Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_175"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_175"></span>**<sup>175</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_175)In fact, some of these and a number of later acts were claimed by other organizations.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_176"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_176"></span>**<sup>176</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_176)<span style="color:#FF6600">The Manifesto of Umkhonto was issued on the day that operations commenced. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_177"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_177"></span>**<sup>177</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_177)The response to our actions and Manifesto among the white population was characteristically violent. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_178"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_178"></span>**<sup>178</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_178)The Government threatened to take strong action, and called upon its supporters to stand firm and to ignore the demands of the Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_179"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_179"></span>**<sup>179</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_179)The Whites failed to respond by suggesting change; they responded to our call by suggesting the laager.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_180"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_180"></span>**<sup>180</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_180)<span style="color:#FF6600">In contrast, the response of the Africans was one of encouragement. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_181"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_181"></span>**<sup>181</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_181)Suddenly there was hope again. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_182"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_182"></span>**<sup>182</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_182)Things were happening. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_183"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_183"></span>**<sup>183</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_183)People in the townships became eager for political news. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_184"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_184"></span>**<sup>184</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_184)A great deal of enthusiasm was generated by the initial successes, and people began to speculate on how soon freedom would be obtained.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_185"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_185"></span>**<sup>185</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_185)<span style="color:#FF6600">But we in Umkhonto weighed up the white response with anxiety. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_186"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_186"></span>**<sup>186</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_186)The lines were being drawn. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_187"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_187"></span>**<sup>187</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_187)The whites and blacks were moving into separate camps, and the prospects of avoiding a civil war were made less. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_188"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_188"></span>**<sup>188</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_188)The white newspapers carried reports that sabotage would be punished by death. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_189"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_189"></span>**<sup>189</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_189)If this was so, how could we continue to keep Africans away from terrorism?</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_190"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_190"></span>**<sup>190</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_190)Already scores of Africans had died as a result of racial friction. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_191"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_191"></span>**<sup>191</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_191)In 1920 when the famous leader, Masabala, was held in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Port Elizabeth</st1:city></st1:place> jail, twenty-four of a group of Africans who had gathered to demand his release were killed by the police and white civilians. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_192"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_192"></span>**<sup>192</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_192)In 1921 more than one hundred Africans died in the Bulhoek affair. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_193"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_193"></span>**<sup>193</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_193)In 1924 over two hundred Africans were killed when the Administrator of South-West Africa led a force against a group which had rebelled against the imposition of dog tax. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_194"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_194"></span>**<sup>194</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_194)On 1 May 1950, eighteen Africans died as a result of police shootings during the strike. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_195"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_195"></span>**<sup>195</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_195)On 21 March 1960, sixty-nine unarmed Africans died at Sharpeville.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_196"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_196"></span>**<sup>196</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_196)How many more Sharpevilles would there be in the history of our country? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_197"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_197"></span>**<sup>197</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_197)And how many more Sharpevilles could the country stand without violence and terror becoming the order of the day? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_198"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_198"></span>**<sup>198</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_198)And what would happen to our people when that stage was reached? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_199"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_199"></span>**<sup>199</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_199)In the long run we felt certain we must succeed, but at what cost to ourselves and the rest of the country? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_200"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_200"></span>**<sup>200</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_200)And if this happened, how could black and white ever live together again in peace and harmony? <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_201"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_201"></span>**<sup>201</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_201)These were the problems that faced us, and these were our decisions.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_202"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_202"></span>**<sup>202</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_202)<span style="color:#FF6600">Experience convinced us that rebellion would offer the Government limitless opportunities for the indiscriminate slaughter of our people. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_203"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_203"></span>**<sup>203</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_203)But it was precisely because the soil of <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> is already drenched with the blood of innocent Africans that we felt it our duty to make preparations as a long-term undertaking to use force in order to defend ourselves against force. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_204"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_204"></span>**<sup>204</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_204)If war were inevitable, we wanted the fight to be conducted on terms most favorable to our people. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_205"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_205"></span>**<sup>205</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_205)The fight which held out prospects best for us and the least risk of life to both sides was guerrilla warfare. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_206"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_206"></span>**<sup>206</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_206)We decided, therefore, in our preparations for the future, to make provision for the possibility of guerrilla warfare.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_207"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_207"></span>**<sup>207</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_207)<span style="color:#FF6600">All whites undergo compulsory military training, but no such training was given to Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_208"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_208"></span>**<sup>208</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_208)It was in our view essential to build up a nucleus of trained men who would be able to provide the leadership which would be required if guerrilla warfare started. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_209"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_209"></span>**<sup>209</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_209)We had to prepare for such a situation before it became too late to make proper preparations. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_210"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_210"></span>**<sup>210</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_210)It was also necessary to build up a nucleus of men trained in civil administration and other professions, so that Africans would be equipped to participate in the government of this country as soon as they were allowed to do so.</span>

**<sup><span style="color:#FF6600">[211](#E_dienvan_v_22_211)</span></sup>**<span style="color:#FF6600">At this stage it was decided that I should attend the Conference of the Pan-African Freedom Movement for Central, East, and Southern Africa, which was to be held early in 1962 in Addis Ababa, and, because of our need for preparation, it was also decided that, after the conference, I would undertake a tour of the African States with a view to obtaining facilities for the training of soldiers, and that I would also solicit scholarships for the higher education of matriculated Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_212"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_212"></span>**<sup>212</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_212)Training in both fields would be necessary, even if changes came about by peaceful means.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_213"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_213"></span>**<sup>213</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_213)<span style="color:#FF6600">Administrators would be necessary who would be willing and able to administer a non-racial State and so would men be necessary to control the army and police force of such a State.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_214"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_214"></span>**<sup>214</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_214)<span style="color:#FF6600">It was on this note that I left <st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region> to proceed to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Addis Ababa</st1:city></st1:place> as a delegate of the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_215"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_215"></span>**<sup>215</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_215)My tour was a success. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_211"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_211"></span>**<sup>211</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_211)Wherever I went I met sympathy for our cause and promises of help. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_216"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_216"></span>**<sup>216</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_216)All Africa was united against the stand of White South Africa, and even in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">London</st1:city></st1:place> I was received with great sympathy by political leaders, such as Mr. Gaitskell and Mr. Grimond. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_217"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_217"></span>**<sup>217</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_217)In Africa I was promised support by such men as Julius Nyerere, now President of Tanganyika; Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_218"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_218"></span>**<sup>218</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_218)Kawawa, then Prime Minister of Tanganyika; Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia; General Abboud, President of the Sudan; Habib Bourguiba, President of Tunisia; Ben Bella, now President of Algeria; Modibo Keita, President of Mali; Leopold Senghor, President of Senegal; Sekou Toure, President of Guinea; President Tubman of Liberia; and Milton Obote, Prime Minister of Uganda. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_219"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_219"></span>**<sup>219</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_219)It was Ben Bella who invited me to visit <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Oujda</st1:city></st1:place>, the Headquarters of the Algerian Army of National Liberation, the visit which is described in my diary, one of the Exhibits.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_220"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_220"></span>**<sup>220</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_220)<span style="color:#FF6600">I started to make a study of the art of war and revolution and, whilst abroad, underwent a course in military training. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_221"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_221"></span>**<sup>221</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_221)If there was to be guerrilla warfare, I wanted to be able to stand and fight with my people and to share the hazards of war with them. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_222"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_222"></span>**<sup>222</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_222)Notes of lectures which I received in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Algeria</st1:country-region></st1:place> are contained in Exhibit 16, produced in evidence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_223"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_223"></span>**<sup>223</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_223)Summaries of books on guerrilla warfare and military strategy have also been produced. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_224"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_224"></span>**<sup>224</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_224)I have already admitted that these documents are in my writing, and I acknowledge that I made these studies to equip myself for the role which I might have to play if the struggle drifted into guerrilla warfare. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_225"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_225"></span>**<sup>225</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_225)I approached this question as every African Nationalist should do. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_226"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_226"></span>**<sup>226</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_226)I was completely objective. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_227"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_227"></span>**<sup>227</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_227)The Court will see that I attempted to examine all types of authority on the subject – from the East and from the West, going back to the classic work of Clausewitz, and covering such a variety as Mao Tse Tung and Che Guevara on the one hand, and the writings on the Anglo-Boer War on the other. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_228"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_228"></span>**<sup>228</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_228)Of course, these notes are merely summaries of the books I read and do not contain my personal views.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_229"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_229"></span>**<sup>229</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_229)<span style="color:#FF6600">I also made arrangements for our recruits to undergo military training. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_230"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_230"></span>**<sup>230</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_230)But here it was impossible to organize any scheme without the co-operation of the ANC offices in <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_231"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_231"></span>**<sup>231</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_231)I consequently obtained the permission of the ANC in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> to do this. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_232"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_232"></span>**<sup>232</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_232)To this extent then there was a departure from the original decision of the ANC, but it applied outside <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> only. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_233"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_233"></span>**<sup>233</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_233)The first batch of recruits actually arrived in <st1:country-region w:st="on">Tanganyika</st1:country-region> when I was passing through that country on my way back to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place>.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_234"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_234"></span>**<sup>234</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_234)<span style="color:#FF6600">I returned to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> and reported to my colleagues on the results of my trip. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_235"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_235"></span>**<sup>235</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_235)On my return I found that there had been little alteration in the political scene save that the threat of a death penalty for sabotage had now become a fact. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_236"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_236"></span>**<sup>236</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_236)The attitude of my colleagues in Umkhonto was much the same as it had been before I left. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_237"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_237"></span>**<sup>237</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_237)They were feeling their way cautiously and felt that it would be a long time before the possibilities of sabotage were exhausted. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_238"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_238"></span>**<sup>238</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_238)In fact, the view was expressed by some that the training of recruits was premature. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_239"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_239"></span>**<sup>239</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_239)This is recorded by me in the document which is Exhibit R.14\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_240"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_240"></span>**<sup>240</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_240)After a full discussion, however, it was decided to go ahead with the plans for military training because of the fact that it would take many years to build up a sufficient nucleus of trained soldiers to start a guerrilla campaign, and whatever happened, the training would be of value.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_241"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_241"></span>**<sup>241</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_241)<span style="color:#FF6600">I wish to turn now to certain general allegations made in this case by the State. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_242"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_242"></span>**<sup>242</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_242)But before doing so, I wish to revert to certain occurrences said by witnesses to have happened in <st1:city w:st="on">Port Elizabeth</st1:city> and <st1:place w:st="on">East London</st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_243"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_243"></span>**<sup>243</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_243)I am referring to the bombing of private houses of pro-Government persons during September, October and November 1962\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_244"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_244"></span>**<sup>244</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_244)I do not know what justification there was for these acts, nor what provocation had been given. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_245"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_245"></span>**<sup>245</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_245)But if what I have said already is accepted, then it is clear that these acts had nothing to do with the carrying out of the policy of Umkhonto.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_246"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_246"></span>**<sup>246</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_246)<span style="color:#FF6600">One of the chief allegations in the indictment is that the ANC was a party to a general conspiracy to commit sabotage. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_247"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_247"></span>**<sup>247</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_247)I have already explained why this is incorrect but how, externally, there was a departure from the original principle laid down by the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_248"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_248"></span>**<sup>248</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_248)There has, of course, been overlapping of functions internally as well, because there is a difference between a resolution adopted in the atmosphere of a committee room and the concrete difficulties that arise in the field of practical activity. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_249"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_249"></span>**<sup>249</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_249)At a later stage the position was further affected by bannings and house arrests, and by persons leaving the country to take up political work abroad. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_250"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_250"></span>**<sup>250</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_250)This led to individuals having to do work in different capacities. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_251"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_251"></span>**<sup>251</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_251)But though this may have blurred the distinction between Umkhonto and the ANC, it by no means abolished that distinction. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_252"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_252"></span>**<sup>252</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_252)Great care was taken to keep the activities of the two organizations in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> distinct. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_253"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_253"></span>**<sup>253</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_253)The ANC remained a mass political body of Africans only carrying on the type of political work they had conducted prior to 1961\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_254"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_254"></span>**<sup>254</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_254)Umkhonto remained a small organization recruiting its members from different races and organizations and trying to achieve its own particular object. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_255"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_255"></span>**<sup>255</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_255)The fact that members of Umkhonto were recruited from the ANC, and the fact that persons served both organizations, like Solomon Mbanjwa, did not, in our view, change the nature of the ANC or give it a policy of violence. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_256"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_256"></span>**<sup>256</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_256)This overlapping of officers, however, was more the exception than the rule. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_257"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_257"></span>**<sup>257</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_257)This is why persons such as ‘Mr. X’ and ‘Mr. Z,’ who were on the Regional Command of their respective areas, did not participate in any of the ANC committees or activities, and why people such as Mr. Bennett Mashiyana and Mr. Reginald Ndubi did not hear of sabotage at their ANC meetings.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_258"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_258"></span>**<sup>258</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_258)<span style="color:#FF6600">Another of the allegations in the indictment is that Rivonia was the headquarters of Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_259"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_259"></span>**<sup>259</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_259)This is not true of the time when I was there. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_260"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_260"></span>**<sup>260</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_260)I was told, of course, and knew that certain of the activities of the Communist Party were carried on there. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_261"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_261"></span>**<sup>261</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_261)But this is no reason (as I shall presently explain) why I should not use the place.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_262"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_262"></span>**<sup>262</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_262)<span style="color:#FF6600">I came there in the following manner:</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_263"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_263"></span>**<sup>263</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_263)As already indicated, early in April 1961 I went underground to organize the May general strike. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_264"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_264"></span>**<sup>264</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_264)My work entailed travelling throughout the country, living now in African townships, then in country villages and again in cities.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_265"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_265"></span>**<sup>265</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_265)During the second half of the year I started visiting the Parktown home of Arthur Goldreich, where I used to meet my family privately. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_266"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_266"></span>**<sup>266</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_266)Although I had no direct political association with him, I had known Arthur Goldreich socially since 1958.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_267"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_267"></span>**<sup>267</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_267)In October, Arthur Goldreich informed me that he was moving out of town and offered me a hiding place there. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_268"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_268"></span>**<sup>268</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_268)A few days thereafter, he arranged for Michael Harmel to take me to Rivonia. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_269"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_269"></span>**<sup>269</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_269)I naturally found Rivonia an ideal place for the man who lived the life of an outlaw. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_270"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_270"></span>**<sup>270</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_270)Up to that time I had been compelled to live indoors during the daytime and could only venture out under cover of darkness. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_271"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_271"></span>**<sup>271</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_271)But at Liliesleaf [farm, Rivonia,] I could live differently and work far more efficiently.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_272"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_272"></span>**<sup>272</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_272)For obvious reasons, I had to disguise myself and I assumed the fictitious name of David. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_273"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_273"></span>**<sup>273</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_273)In December, Arthur Goldreich and his family moved in. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_274"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_274"></span>**<sup>274</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_274)I stayed there until I went abroad on 11 January 1962\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_275"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_275"></span>**<sup>275</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_275)As already indicated, I returned in July 1962 and was arrested in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Natal</st1:city></st1:place> on 5 August.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_276"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_276"></span>**<sup>276</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_276)Up to the time of my arrest, Liliesleaf farm was the headquarters of neither the African National Congress nor Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_277"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_277"></span>**<sup>277</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_277)With the exception of myself, none of the officials or members of these bodies lived there, no meetings of the governing bodies were ever held there, and no activities connected with them were either organized or directed from there. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_278"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_278"></span>**<sup>278</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_278)On numerous occasions during my stay at Liliesleaf farm I met both the Executive Committee of the ANC, as well as the NHC, but such meetings were held elsewhere and not on the farm.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_279"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_279"></span>**<sup>279</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_279)Whilst staying at Liliesleaf farm, I frequently visited Arthur Goldreich in the main house and he also paid me visits in my room. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_280"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_280"></span>**<sup>280</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_280)We had numerous political discussions covering a variety of subjects. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_281"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_281"></span>**<sup>281</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_281)We discussed ideological and practical questions, the Congress Alliance, Umkhonto and its activities generally, and his experiences as a soldier in the Palmach, the military wing of the Haganah. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_282"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_282"></span>**<sup>282</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_282)Haganah was the political authority of the Jewish National Movement in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Palestine</st1:city></st1:place>.</span>

<span style="color:#FF6600">• <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_283"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_283"></span>**<sup>283</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_283)Because of what I had got to know of Goldreich, I recommended on my return to <st1:country-region w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">South Africa</st1:place></st1:country-region> that he should be recruited to Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_284"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_284"></span>**<sup>284</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_284)I do not know of my personal knowledge whether this was done.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_285"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_285"></span>**<sup>285</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_285)<span style="color:#FF6600">Another of the allegations made by the State is that the aims and objects of the ANC and the Communist Party are the same. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_286"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_286"></span>**<sup>286</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_286)I wish to deal with this and with my own political position, because I must assume that the State may try to argue from certain Exhibits that I tried to introduce Marxism into the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_287"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_287"></span>**<sup>287</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_287)The allegation as to the ANC is false. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_288"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_288"></span>**<sup>288</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_288)This is an old allegation which was disproved at the Treason Trial and which has again reared its head. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_289"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_289"></span>**<sup>289</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_289)But since the allegation has been made again, I shall deal with it as well as with the relationship between the ANC and the Communist Party and Umkhonto and that party.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_290"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_290"></span>**<sup>290</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_290)<span style="color:#FF6600">The ideological creed of the ANC is, and always has been, the creed of African Nationalism. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_291"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_291"></span>**<sup>291</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_291)It is not the concept of African Nationalism expressed in the cry, ‘Drive the White man into the sea.’ <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_292"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_292"></span>**<sup>292</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_292)The African Nationalism for which the ANC stands is the concept of freedom and fulfilment for the African people in their own land. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_293"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_293"></span>**<sup>293</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_293)The most important political document ever adopted by the ANC is the ‘Freedom Charter.’ <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_294"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_294"></span>**<sup>294</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_294)It is by no means a blueprint for a socialist state. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_295"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_295"></span>**<sup>295</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_295)It calls for redistribution, but not nationalization, of land; it provides for nationalization of mines, banks, and monopoly industry, because big monopolies are owned by one race only, and without such nationalization racial domination would be perpetuated despite the spread of political power. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_296"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_296"></span>**<sup>296</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_296)It would be a hollow gesture to repeal the Gold Law prohibitions against Africans when all gold mines are owned by European companies. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_297"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_297"></span>**<sup>297</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_297)In this respect the ANC’s policy corresponds with the old policy of the present Nationalist Party which, for many years, had as part of its programme the nationalization of the gold mines which, at that time, were controlled by foreign capital. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_298"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_298"></span>**<sup>298</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_298)Under the Freedom Charter, nationalization would take place in an economy based on private enterprise. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_299"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_299"></span>**<sup>299</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_299)The realization of the Freedom Charter would open up fresh fields for a prosperous African population of all classes, including the middle class. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_300"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_300"></span>**<sup>300</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_300)The ANC has never at any period of its history advocated a revolutionary change in the economic structure of the country, nor has it, to the best of my recollection, ever condemned capitalist society.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_301"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_301"></span>**<sup>301</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_301)<span style="color:#FF6600">As far as the Communist Party is concerned, and if I understand its policy correctly, it stands for the establishment of a State based on the principles of Marxism. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_302"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_302"></span>**<sup>302</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_302)Although it is prepared to work for the Freedom Charter, as a short term solution to the problems created by white supremacy, it regards the Freedom Charter as the beginning, and not the end, of its program.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_303"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_303"></span>**<sup>303</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_303)<span style="color:#FF6600">The ANC, unlike the Communist Party, admitted Africans only as members. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_304"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_304"></span>**<sup>304</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_304)Its chief goal was, and is, for the African people to win unity and full political rights. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_305"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_305"></span>**<sup>305</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_305)The Communist Party’s main aim, on the other hand, was to remove the capitalists and to replace them with a working-class government. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_306"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_306"></span>**<sup>306</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_306)The Communist Party sought to emphasize class distinctions whilst the ANC seeks to harmonize them. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_307"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_307"></span>**<sup>307</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_307)This is a vital distinction.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_308"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_308"></span>**<sup>308</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_308)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is true that there has often been close co-operation between the ANC and the Communist Party. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_309"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_309"></span>**<sup>309</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_309)But co-operation is merely proof of a common goal – in this case the removal of white supremacy – and is not proof of a complete community of interests.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_310"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_310"></span>**<sup>310</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_310)<span style="color:#FF6600">The history of the world is full of similar examples. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_311"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_311"></span>**<sup>311</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_311)Perhaps the most striking illustration is to be found in the co-operation between <st1:country-region w:st="on">Great Britain</st1:country-region>, the <st1:country-region w:st="on">United States of America</st1:country-region>, and the <st1:place w:st="on">Soviet Union</st1:place> in the fight against Hitler. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_312"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_312"></span>**<sup>312</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_312)Nobody but Hitler would have dared to suggest that such co-operation turned Churchill or Roosevelt into communists or communist tools, or that <st1:country-region w:st="on">Britain</st1:country-region> and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">America</st1:country-region></st1:place> were working to bring about a communist world.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_313"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_313"></span>**<sup>313</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_313)<span style="color:#FF6600">Another instance of such co-operation is to be found precisely in Umkhonto. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_314"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_314"></span>**<sup>314</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_314)Shortly after Umkhonto was constituted, I was informed by some of its members that the Communist Party would support Umkhonto, and this then occurred. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_315"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_315"></span>**<sup>315</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_315)At a later stage the support was made openly.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_316"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_316"></span>**<sup>316</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_316)<span style="color:#FF6600">I believe that communists have always played an active role in the fight by colonial countries for their freedom, because the short-term objects of communism would always correspond with the long-term objects of freedom movements. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_317"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_317"></span>**<sup>317</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_317)Thus communists have played an important role in the freedom struggles fought in countries such as <st1:city w:st="on">Malaya</st1:city>, <st1:country-region w:st="on">Algeria</st1:country-region>, and <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Indonesia</st1:country-region></st1:place>, yet none of these States today are communist countries. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_318"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_318"></span>**<sup>318</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_318)Similarly in the underground resistance movements which sprung up in <st1:place w:st="on">Europe</st1:place> during the last World War, communists played an important role. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_319"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_319"></span>**<sup>319</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_319)Even General Chiang Kai-Shek, today one of the bitterest enemies of communism, fought together with the communists against the ruling class in the struggle which led to his assumption of power in China in the 1930s.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_320"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_320"></span>**<sup>320</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_320)<span style="color:#FF6600">This pattern of co-operation between communists and non-communists has been repeated in the National Liberation Movement of South Africa. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_321"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_321"></span>**<sup>321</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_321)Prior to the banning of the Communist Party, joint campaigns involving the Communist Party and the Congress movements were accepted practice. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_322"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_322"></span>**<sup>322</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_322)African communists could, and did, become members of the ANC, and some served on the National, Provincial, and local committees. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_323"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_323"></span>**<sup>323</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_323)Amongst those who served on the National Executive are Albert Nzula, a former Secretary of the Communist Party, Moses Kotane, another former Secretary, and J. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_324"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_324"></span>**<sup>324</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_324)B. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_325"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_325"></span>**<sup>325</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_325)Marks, a former member of the Central Committee.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_326"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_326"></span>**<sup>326</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_326)<span style="color:#FF6600">I joined the ANC in 1944, and in my younger days I held the view that the policy of admitting communists to the ANC, and the close co-operation which existed at times on specific issues between the ANC and the Communist Party, would lead to a watering down of the concept of African Nationalism. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_327"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_327"></span>**<sup>327</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_327)At that stage I was a member of the African National Congress Youth League, and was one of a group which moved for the expulsion of communists from the ANC. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_328"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_328"></span>**<sup>328</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_328)This proposal was heavily defeated. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_329"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_329"></span>**<sup>329</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_329)Amongst those who voted against the proposal were some of the most conservative sections of African political opinion. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_330"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_330"></span>**<sup>330</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_330)They defended the policy on the ground that from its inception the ANC was formed and built up, not as a political party with one school of political thought, but as a Parliament of the African people, accommodating people of various political convictions, all united by the common goal of national liberation. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_331"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_331"></span>**<sup>331</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_331)I was eventually won over to this point of view and I have upheld it ever since.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_332"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_332"></span>**<sup>332</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_332)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is perhaps difficult for white South Africans, with an ingrained prejudice against communism, to understand why experienced African politicians so readily accept communists as their friends. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_333"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_333"></span>**<sup>333</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_333)But to us the reason is obvious. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_334"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_334"></span>**<sup>334</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_334)Theoretical differences amongst those fighting against oppression is a luxury we cannot afford at this stage. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_335"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_335"></span>**<sup>335</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_335)What is more, for many decades communists were the only political group in South Africa who were prepared to treat Africans as human beings and their equals; who were prepared to eat with us; talk with us, live with us, and work with us. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_336"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_336"></span>**<sup>336</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_336)They were the only political group which was prepared to work with the Africans for the attainment of political rights and a stake in society. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_337"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_337"></span>**<sup>337</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_337)Because of this, there are many Africans who, today, tend to equate freedom with communism. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_338"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_338"></span>**<sup>338</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_338)They are supported in this belief by a legislature which brands all exponents of democratic government and African freedom as communists and bans many of them (who are not communists) under the Suppression of Communism Act. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_339"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_339"></span>**<sup>339</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_339)Although I have never been a member of the Communist Party, I myself have been named under that pernicious Act because of the role I played in the Defiance Campaign. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_340"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_340"></span>**<sup>340</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_340)I have also been banned and imprisoned under that Act.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_341"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_341"></span>**<sup>341</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_341)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is not only in internal politics that we count communists as amongst those who support our cause. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_342"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_342"></span>**<sup>342</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_342)In the international field, communist countries have always come to our aid. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_343"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_343"></span>**<sup>343</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_343)In the United Nations and other Councils of the world the communist bloc has supported the Afro-Asian struggle against colonialism and often seems to be more sympathetic to our plight than some of the Western powers. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_344"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_344"></span>**<sup>344</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_344)Although there is a universal condemnation of apartheid, the communist bloc speaks out against it with a louder voice than most of the white world. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_345"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_345"></span>**<sup>345</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_345)In these circumstances, it would take a brash young politician, such as I was in 1949, to proclaim that the Communists are our enemies.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_346"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_346"></span>**<sup>346</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_346)<span style="color:#FF6600">I turn now to my own position. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_347"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_347"></span>**<sup>347</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_347)I have denied that I am a communist, and I think that in the circumstances I am obliged to state exactly what my political beliefs are.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_348"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_348"></span>**<sup>348</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_348)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have always regarded myself, in the first place, as an African patriot. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_349"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_349"></span>**<sup>349</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_349)After all, I was born in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Umtata</st1:city></st1:place>, forty-six years ago. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_350"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_350"></span>**<sup>350</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_350)My guardian was my cousin, who was the acting paramount chief of Tembuland, and I am related both to the present paramount chief of Tembuland, Sabata Dalindyebo, and to Kaizer Matanzima, the Chief Minister of the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Transkei</st1:country-region></st1:place>.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_351"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_351"></span>**<sup>351</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_351)<span style="color:#FF6600">Today I am attracted by the idea of a classless society, an attraction which springs in part from Marxist reading and, in part, from my admiration of the structure and organization of early African societies in this country. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_352"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_352"></span>**<sup>352</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_352)The land, then the main means of production, belonged to the tribe. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_353"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_353"></span>**<sup>353</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_353)There were no rich or poor and there was no exploitation.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_354"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_354"></span>**<sup>354</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_354)<span style="color:#FF6600">It is true, as I have already stated, that I have been influenced by Marxist thought. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_355"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_355"></span>**<sup>355</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_355)But this is also true of many of the leaders of the new independent States. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_356"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_356"></span>**<sup>356</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_356)Such widely different persons as Gandhi, Nehru, Nkrumah, and Nasser all acknowledge this fact. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_357"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_357"></span>**<sup>357</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_357)We all accept the need for some form of socialism to enable our people to catch up with the advanced countries of this world and to overcome their legacy of extreme poverty. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_358"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_358"></span>**<sup>358</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_358)But this does not mean we are Marxists.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_359"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_359"></span>**<sup>359</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_359)<span style="color:#FF6600">Indeed, for my own part, I believe that it is open to debate whether the Communist Party has any specific role to play at this particular stage of our political struggle. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_360"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_360"></span>**<sup>360</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_360)The basic task at the present moment is the removal of race discrimination and the attainment of democratic rights on the basis of the Freedom Charter. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_361"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_361"></span>**<sup>361</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_361)In so far as that Party furthers this task, I welcome its assistance. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_362"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_362"></span>**<sup>362</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_362)I realize that it is one of the means by which people of all races can be drawn into our struggle.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_363"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_363"></span>**<sup>363</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_363)<span style="color:#FF6600">From my reading of Marxist literature and from conversations with Marxists, I have gained the impression that communists regard the parliamentary system of the West as undemocratic and reactionary. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_364"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_364"></span>**<sup>364</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_364)But, on the contrary, I am an admirer of such a system.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_365"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_365"></span>**<sup>365</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_365)<span style="color:#FF6600">The Magna Carta, the Petition of Rights, and the Bill of Rights are documents which are held in veneration by democrats throughout the world.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_366"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_366"></span>**<sup>366</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_366)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have great respect for British political institutions, and for the country’s system of justice. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_367"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_367"></span>**<sup>367</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_367)I regard the British Parliament as the most democratic institution in the world, and the independence and impartiality of its judiciary never fails to arouse my admiration.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_368"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_368"></span>**<sup>368</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_368)<span style="color:#FF6600">The American Congress, that country’s doctrine of separation of powers, as well as the independence of its judiciary, arouses in me similar sentiments.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_369"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_369"></span>**<sup>369</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_369)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have been influenced in my thinking by both West and East. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_370"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_370"></span>**<sup>370</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_370)All this has led me to feel that in my search for a political formula, I should be absolutely impartial and objective. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_371"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_371"></span>**<sup>371</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_371)I should tie myself to no particular system of society other than of socialism. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_372"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_372"></span>**<sup>372</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_372)I must leave myself free to borrow the best from the West and from the East...</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_373"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_373"></span>**<sup>373</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_373)<span style="color:#FF6600">There are certain Exhibits which suggest that we received financial support from abroad, and I wish to deal with this question.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_374"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_374"></span>**<sup>374</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_374)<span style="color:#FF6600">Our political struggle has always been financed from internal sources – from funds raised by our own people and by our own supporters. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_375"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_375"></span>**<sup>375</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_375)Whenever we had a special campaign or an important political case – for example, the Treason Trial – we received financial assistance from sympathetic individuals and organizations in the Western countries. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_376"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_376"></span>**<sup>376</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_376)We had never felt it necessary to go beyond these sources.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_377"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_377"></span>**<sup>377</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_377)<span style="color:#FF6600">But when in 1961 the Umkhonto was formed, and a new phase of struggle introduced, we realized that these events would make a heavy call on our slender resources, and that the scale of our activities would be hampered by the lack of funds. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_378"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_378"></span>**<sup>378</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_378)One of my instructions, as I went abroad in January 1962, was to raise funds from the African states.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_379"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_379"></span>**<sup>379</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_379)<span style="color:#FF6600">I must add that, whilst abroad, I had discussions with leaders of political movements in Africa and discovered that almost every single one of them, in areas which had still not attained independence, had received all forms of assistance from the socialist countries, as well as from the West, including that of financial support. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_380"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_380"></span>**<sup>380</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_380)I also discovered that some well-known African states, all of them non-communists, and even anti-communists, had received similar assistance.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_381"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_381"></span>**<sup>381</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_381)<span style="color:#FF6600">On my return to the Republic, I made a strong recommendation to the ANC that we should not confine ourselves to <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place> and the Western countries, but that we should also send a mission to the socialist countries to raise the funds which we so urgently needed.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_382"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_382"></span>**<sup>382</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_382)<span style="color:#FF6600">I have been told that after I was convicted such a mission was sent, but I am not prepared to name any countries to which it went, nor am I at liberty to disclose the names of the organizations and countries which gave us support or promised to do so.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_383"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_383"></span>**<sup>383</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_383)<span style="color:#FF6600">As I understand the State case, and in particular the evidence of ‘Mr. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_384"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_384"></span>**<sup>384</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_384)X,’ the suggestion is that Umkhonto was the inspiration of the Communist Party which sought by playing upon imaginary grievances to enroll the African people into an army which ostensibly was to fight for African freedom, but in reality was fighting for a communist state. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_385"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_385"></span>**<sup>385</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_385)Nothing could be further from the truth. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_386"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_386"></span>**<sup>386</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_386)In fact the suggestion is preposterous. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_387"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_387"></span>**<sup>387</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_387)Umkhonto was formed by Africans to further their struggle for freedom in their own land. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_388"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_388"></span>**<sup>388</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_388)Communists and others supported the movement, and we only wish that more sections of the community would join us.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_389"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_389"></span>**<sup>389</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_389)Our fight is against real, and not imaginary, hardships or, to use the language of the State Prosecutor, ‘so-called hardships.’ <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_390"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_390"></span>**<sup>390</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_390)Basically, we fight against two features which are the hallmarks of African life in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> and which are entrenched by legislation which we seek to have repealed. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_391"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_391"></span>**<sup>391</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_391)These features are poverty and lack of human dignity, and we do not need communists or so-called ‘agitators’ to teach us about these things.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_392"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_392"></span>**<sup>392</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_392)<st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region> is the richest country in <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place>, and could be one of the richest countries in the world. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_393"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_393"></span>**<sup>393</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_393)But it is a land of extremes and remarkable contrasts. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_394"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_394"></span>**<sup>394</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_394)The whites enjoy what may well be the highest standard of living in the world, whilst Africans live in poverty and misery. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_395"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_395"></span>**<sup>395</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_395)Forty per cent of the Africans live in hopelessly overcrowded and, in some cases, drought-stricken Reserves, where soil erosion and the overworking of the soil makes it impossible for them to live properly off the land. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_396"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_396"></span>**<sup>396</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_396)Thirty per cent are laborers, labor tenants, and squatters on white farms and work and live under conditions similar to those of the serfs of the Middle Ages. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_397"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_397"></span>**<sup>397</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_397)The other 30 per cent live in towns where they have developed economic and social habits which bring them closer in many respects to white standards. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_398"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_398"></span>**<sup>398</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_398)Yet most Africans, even in this group, are impoverished by low incomes and high cost of living.

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_399"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_399"></span>**<sup>399</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_399)<span style="color:#FF6600">The highest-paid and the most prosperous section of urban African life is in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_400"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_400"></span>**<sup>400</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_400)Yet their actual position is desperate. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_401"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_401"></span>**<sup>401</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_401)The latest figures were given on 25 March 1964 by Mr. Carr, Manager of the Johannesburg Non-European Affairs Department. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_402"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_402"></span>**<sup>402</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_402)The poverty datum line for the average African family in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place> (according to Mr. Carr’s department) is R42.84 per month. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_403"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_403"></span>**<sup>403</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_403)He showed that the average monthly wage is R32.24 and that 46 per cent of all African families in <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Johannesburg</st1:city></st1:place> do not earn enough to keep them going.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_404"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_404"></span>**<sup>404</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_404)Poverty goes hand in hand with malnutrition and disease. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_405"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_405"></span>**<sup>405</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_405)The incidence of malnutrition and deficiency diseases is very high amongst Africans. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_406"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_406"></span>**<sup>406</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_406)<span style="color:#FF6600">Tuberculosis, pellagra, kwashiorkor, gastro-enteritis, and scurvy bring death and destruction of health. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_407"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_407"></span>**<sup>407</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_407)The incidence of infant mortality is one of the highest in the world. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_408"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_408"></span>**<sup>408</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_408)According to the Medical Officer of Health for <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Pretoria</st1:city></st1:place>, tuberculosis kills forty people a day (almost all Africans), and in 1961 there were 58,491 new cases reported. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_409"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_409"></span>**<sup>409</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_409)These diseases not only destroy the vital organs of the body, but they result in retarded mental conditions and lack of initiative, and reduce powers of concentration. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_410"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_410"></span>**<sup>410</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_410)The secondary results of such conditions affect the whole community and the standard of work performed by African laborers.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_411"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_411"></span>**<sup>411</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_411)<span style="color:#FF6600">The complaint of Africans, however, is not only that they are poor and the whites are rich, but that the laws which are made by the whites are designed to preserve this situation. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_412"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_412"></span>**<sup>412</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_412)There are two ways to break out of poverty. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_413"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_413"></span>**<sup>413</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_413)The first is by formal education, and the second is by the worker acquiring a greater skill at his work and thus higher wages. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_414"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_414"></span>**<sup>414</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_414)As far as Africans are concerned, both these avenues of advancement are deliberately curtailed by legislation.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_415"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_415"></span>**<sup>415</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_415)<span style="color:#FF6600">The present Government has always sought to hamper Africans in their search for education. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_416"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_416"></span>**<sup>416</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_416)One of their early acts, after coming into power, was to stop subsidies for African school feeding. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_417"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_417"></span>**<sup>417</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_417)Many African children who attended schools depended on this supplement to their diet. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_418"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_418"></span>**<sup>418</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_418)This was a cruel act.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_419"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_419"></span>**<sup>419</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_419)<span style="color:#FF6600">There is compulsory education for all white children at virtually no cost to their parents, be they rich or poor. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_420"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_420"></span>**<sup>420</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_420)Similar facilities are not provided for the African children, though there are some who receive such assistance. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_421"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_421"></span>**<sup>421</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_421)African children, however, generally have to pay more for their schooling than whites. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_422"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_422"></span>**<sup>422</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_422)According to figures quoted by the South African Institute of Race Relations in its 1963 journal, approximately 40 per cent of African children in the age group between seven to fourteen do not attend school. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_423"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_423"></span>**<sup>423</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_423)For those who do attend school, the standards are vastly different from those afforded to white children. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_424"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_424"></span>**<sup>424</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_424)In 1960-61 the per capita Government spending on African students at State-aided schools was estimated at R12.46\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_425"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_425"></span>**<sup>425</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_425)In the same years, the per capita spending on white children in the <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:state w:st="on">Cape Province</st1:state></st1:place> (which are the only figures available to me) was R144.57\. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_426"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_426"></span>**<sup>426</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_426)Although there are no figures available to me, it can be stated, without doubt, that the white children on whom R144.57 per head was being spent all came from wealthier homes than African children on whom R12.46 per head was being spent.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_427"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_427"></span>**<sup>427</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_427)<span style="color:#FF6600">The quality of education is also different. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_428"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_428"></span>**<sup>428</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_428)According to the Bantu Educational Journal, only 5,660 African children in the whole of <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region></st1:place> passed their Junior Certificate in 1962, and in that year only 362 passed matric. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_429"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_429"></span>**<sup>429</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_429)This is presumably consistent with the policy of Bantu education about which the present Prime Minister said, during the debate on the Bantu Education Bill in 1953:</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_430"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_430"></span>**<sup>430</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_430)<span style="color:#FF6600">“When I have control of Native education I will reform it so that Natives will be taught from childhood to realize that equality with Europeans is not for them... <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_431"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_431"></span>**<sup>431</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_431)People who believe in equality are not desirable teachers for Natives. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_432"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_432"></span>**<sup>432</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_432)When my Department controls Native education it will know for what class of higher education a Native is fitted, and whether he will have a chance in life to use his knowledge.”</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_433"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_433"></span>**<sup>433</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_433)<span style="color:#FF6600">The other main obstacle to the economic advancement of the African is the industrial color-bar under which all the better jobs of industry are reserved for Whites only. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_434"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_434"></span>**<sup>434</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_434)Moreover, Africans who do obtain employment in the unskilled and semi-skilled occupations which are open to them are not allowed to form trade unions which have recognition under the Industrial Conciliation Act. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_435"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_435"></span>**<sup>435</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_435)This means that strikes of African workers are illegal, and that they are denied the right of collective bargaining which is permitted to the better-paid White workers. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_436"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_436"></span>**<sup>436</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_436)The discrimination in the policy of successive South African Governments towards African workers is demonstrated by the so-called ‘civilized labor policy’ under which sheltered, unskilled Government jobs are found for those white workers who cannot make the grade in industry, at wages which far exceed the earnings of the average African employee in industry.</span>

<a name="E_dienvan_e_22_437"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_437"></span>**<sup>437</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_437)<span style="color:#FF6600">The Government often answers its critics by saying that Africans in <st1:country-region w:st="on">South Africa</st1:country-region> are economically better off than the inhabitants of the other countries in <st1:place w:st="on">Africa</st1:place>. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_438"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_438"></span>**<sup>438</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_438)I do not know whether this statement is true and doubt whether any comparison can be made without having regard to the cost-of-living index in such countries. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_439"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_439"></span>**<sup>439</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_439)But even if it is true, as far as the African people are concerned it is irrelevant. <a name="E_dienvan_e_22_440"></a>[<span style="mso-bookmark:E_dienvan_e_22_440"></span>**<sup>440</sup>**](#E_dienvan_v_22_440)Our complaint is not that we are poor by comparison with people in other countries, but that we are poor by comparison with the white people in our own country, and that we are prevented by legislation from altering this imbalance.</span>
